urn:contentItem:531N-1YM1-DYVR-5424-00000-00Fourteenth NewsWatch2011-06-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:17:33ZLexisNexisGENERAL AND NATIONAL NEWSFourteenth NewsWatchCP

(HKN-Stanley Cup) (Audio: 143)

Vancouver Canucks forward Daniel Sedin says there's going to be some nerves tonight for Game One of the Stanley Cup final against Boston.

But he says if you don't have nerves tonight, he thinks there's something wrong with you.

The Canucks have taken advantage of home ice, winning all three of their opening games through the previous rounds.

Forward Alex Burrows says the team wants to feed off the energy of the crowd and focus on what it has to do to be successful so it can have a good first game tonight. (14)

(Sask-Forest-Fire) (Audio: 151)

Smoke from an out-of-control forest fire is blowing across the runway, and has closed the airport in the northern Saskatchewan hamlet of Wollaston Lake.

Now there's no way out for 14-hundred residents who have been told to leave.

Officials are hoping for a shift in the wind direction and moving residents into buildings with air-conditioning.

The fire covering about five square kilometres is one kilometre from the community. (14)

(Climate-Confusion) (Audio: P10)

Researchers say Canada won't be able to meet its greenhouse-gas reduction goals because there's no concerted plan of attack on climate change.

Researchers at the Conference Board of Canada studied federal and provincial policies and say they found a disorganized, inefficient approach.

Lead researcher Len Coad says governments don't talk to each other and most of their action plans don't include concrete goals or detailed analysis that will drive results. (14)

(Harper-Spokesman-Resigns)

Prime Minister Harper's communications director is leaving his post, saying he's going to start a new chapter in his life in September.

Dimitri Soudas is Harper's fifth communications director in his six years in power.

The 31-year-old has had a rocky relationship with the parliamentary press gallery and has often found himself at the centre of controversy. (14)

(US-KKK Candidate)

A former Ku Klux Klan organizer who wants to run for a seat in the U-S Congress believes people will back him as part of a backlash to America's first black president.

But 41-year-old John Abarr could have a hard time getting the nomination from Montana Republicans.

His platform promises to legalize marijuana, abolish the death penalty, which he argues is unfair to poor people, and -- quote -- ''save the White Race.'' (14)

(BKN-Celtics-Shaq-Retires)

Boston Celtics centre Shaquille O'Neal posted a video on his Twitter account today saying he is retiring after 19 years in the N-B-A.

O'Neal is a 15-time all-star who struggled to get on the court this season because of leg injuries.

But Celtics spokesman Jeff Twiss says to his knowledge, O'Neal has not informed the team that he's retiring. (14)

(NewsWatch by Dawn Kelly)

(The Canadian Press)

urn:contentItem:52X6-SDT1-JCCN-F4NR-00000-00Ninth NewsWatch2011-05-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:17:33ZLexisNexisGENERAL AND NATIONAL NEWSNinth NewsWatchCP

(US-Obama-Mideast)

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu will be pressing for clarity in his meeting with U-S President Obama at the White House.

That's after Obama delivered a speech yesterday endorsing the Palestinians' demand that their eventual state be based on borders that existed before the 1967 Six Day War.

That's not a major policy change, but it is the first time he's explicitly endorsed those borders as a starting point, a position Netanyahu rejects. (9)

(Alta-Fires)

Prime Minister Harper and Alberta Premier Ed Stelmach will see the forest fire damage and destruction in Slave Lake today from the air and the ground.

Evacuees finally found out yesterday if they have a home to go back to when provincial officials released maps pinpointing the 374 lots destroyed and the 52 lots damaged.

Firefighters now say that when the forest fire swept into town on Sunday night, they bulldozed 10 homes to build a firebreak.

They say that was responsible for saving many other homes and the local hospital. (9)

(HKN-Thrashers-Future) (Audio: 94)

Fans have been celebrating at the corner of Portage and Main in Winnipeg at a report of a deal to bring the Atlanta Thrashers to the city.

That's even though the N-H-L and True North Sports and Entertainment are disputing the story in The Globe and Mail.

The newspaper says a final announcement will come Tuesday.

Winnipeg lost its N-H-L team in 1996. (9)

(StatsCan-Retail)

March wasn't a spectacular month for Canadian retailers.

Sales were essentially flat, holding steady at 37.3-billion dollars.

The largest dollar increase came at gasoline stations, where sales were up 1.4 per cent, their eighth increase in nine months. (9)

(RBC-Housing-Affordability) (Audio: 93)

It's getting more difficult to afford a home, especially in Vancouver.

R-B-C Economics' latest survey finds that during the first quarter, it took 72.1 per cent of family income to pay for mortgages, property taxes and utilities on a bungalow in Vancouver .

Housing expenses also rose in other major Canadian cities -- but are nowhere near as high as Vancouver.

The bank says home ownership costs could keep rising with the Bank of Canada expected to start raising short-term interest rates soon. (9)

(Sask-Grasslands-Expansion)

One of Canada's national parks is expanding by 111 square kilometres because of a transaction involving a prominent ranching family.

The Dixons have roots in the area near Grasslands National Park in Saskatchewan dating back to the late 19th century.

Grasslands is home to a number of species at risk, like the greater short-horned lizard.

It's also seeing the reintroduction of plains bison, black-tailed prairie dogs and the black-footed ferret. (9)

(NewsWatch by Dawn Kelly)

(The Canadian Press)

urn:contentItem:5K2V-MN81-JBVR-34YD-00000-00Councillors OK hefty pay hike for themselves for Fort McMurray recovery work2016-06-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:17:34ZLexisNexisNATIONALCouncillors OK hefty pay hike for themselves for Fort McMurray recovery workCouncillors OK pay hike for fire recovery workThe Canadian Press

FORT MCMURRAY, Alta. - Councillors from a northeastern Alberta municipality severely damaged by a huge forest fire have voted themselves a hefty raise.

The Rural Municipality of Wood Buffalo includes the city of Fort McMurray, which saw more than 80,000 residents flee from the wildfire that destroyed several neighbourhoods seven weeks ago.

Council voted Tuesday night to pay three of its members and Mayor Melissa Blake $150,000 a year to work full time on a recovery committee.

The other seven councillors, whose positions are considered part time, will see their pay rise to $75,000 a year from $36,000.

Councillors on the recovery committee are Keith McGrath, Sheldon Germain, Allan Vinni and the mayor.

The bylaw passed 7-4, with Blake and councillors Jane Stroud, Phil Meagher and Tyran Ault opposed.

Blake, Stroud and Ault said after the council meeting they will not take the salary increase.

The bylaw states committee members who are also councillors "shall devote their effort and attention to the work of the committee as they would to a full-time job, and thus shall take steps to reduce their time commitment to their other business interests or employment as may be required in order to devote such level of effort and attention to their committee duties for so long as the post-wildfire recovery period lasts."

It says the other councillors "will be required to devote an increased level of effort and attention to their council duties and activities since the normal council and council committee work will continue."

The committee begins work Wednesday and six members of the public are to be appointed following a selection process.

Once all members have been chosen, a chair and vice-chair will be selected.

Coun. Colleen Tatum explained in a Facebook post why she is accepting the pay raise.

"Child care, lost time in my business, lost opportunities elsewhere, do cost me much more than I ever earn," she said. "It does seem obscene on face value, to ask for a raise in these extreme and very hard times, but the justification I do feel is there."

(CJOK)

urn:contentItem:5V83-W9T1-DYG5-73W2-00000-00Canadians can now apply for funding to build wildfire resiliency in Their community2019-01-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:17:33ZLexisNexisCanadians can now apply for funding to build wildfire resiliency in Their community

CO OPERATORS GENERAL INSURANCE COMPANY ("CCS.PR.C-T") - Canadians can now apply for funding to build wildfire resiliency in - Their community

Canadians can now apply for funding to support their local Wildfire Community Preparedness Day activities, and join municipalities from coast to coast in a national effort to reduce wildfire risk to local homes and environments.

Successful applicants can use funding from May 5, 2019 through October to host Wildfire Community Preparedness Day events that raise awareness of wildfire risk, help protect homes, and encourage neighbourhoods to improve wildfire resiliency through "FireSmart" activities including proper maintenance and clearing of dead or combustible vegetation, wildfire-resilient landscaping, and using fire-resistant roofing materials.

This annual, national program was launched by FireSmart Canada in collaboration with The Co-operators, National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) and the Institute for Catastrophic Loss Reduction. In 2018, a total of $47,000 was awarded to 94 successful community applicants across Canada.

"The Wildfire Community Preparedness Day campaign is a very exciting time of year for FireSmart Canada," says Laura Stewart, president of FireSmart Canada. "We are eager to see applications come in from communities who are taking action to reduce the risk of wildfire affecting their community."

Since 2014, The Co-operators has partnered with the NFPA and FireSmart Canada to drive wildfire resiliency efforts and advocacy to mitigate and adapt to the impacts of wildfires across Canada.

"As wildfire seasons become longer and more severe, it is important that Canadians are aware of the risk and actions they can take to help mitigate that risk," says Maya Milardovic, director of Government Relations at The Co-operators. "Through this funding, we are helping communities to come together across the country to take proactive steps to make their communities safer and more resilient."

To learn more about Wildfire Community Preparedness Day and to submit an application for funding, visit: firesmartcanada.ca/wildfire-community-preparedness-day-2019/

About The Co-operators: The Co-operators Group Limited is a Canadian co-operative with more than $42.5 billion in assets under administration. Through its group of companies, it offers home, auto, life, group, travel, commercial and farm insurance, as well as investment products. The Co-operators is well known for its community involvement and its commitment to sustainability. The Co-operators is listed among the Best Employers in Canada by Aon Hewitt and Corporate Knights' Best 50 Corporate Citizens in Canada. For more information, visit www.cooperators.ca

About Fire Smart Canada

FireSmart Canada is the go-to national program committed to helping Canadians reduce their wildfire risk and become fire adapted through community-based solutions. FireSmart is administered by Partners in Protection; a non-profit coalition of federal, provincial, indigenous communities, private industry and municipal fire, emergency and land management experts. Through publications, programs, outreach training, and workshops, FireSmart Canada provides tools for Canadians to become pro-active in reducing the risk of wildfire to their homes and communities. FireSmart programs and products are supported through membership and ongoing active support from organizations such as the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre, the Institute for Catastrophic Loss Reduction, the National Fire Protection Association and The Co-operators. For more information on FireSmart visit www.firesmartcanada.ca.

About NFPA

The National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) is a global non-profit organization, established in 1896, devoted to eliminating death, injury, property and economic loss due to fire, electrical and related hazards. NFPA delivers information and knowledge through more than 300 consensus codes and standards, research, training, education, outreach and advocacy; and by partnering with others who share an interest in furthering our mission. Our mission is to help save lives and reduce loss with information, knowledge and passion. Wildfire Community Preparedness Day is based on or adapted from materials provided and owned by the National Fire Protection Association, a Massachusetts, USA not-for-profit corporation, all rights reserved.

About ICLR

ICLR's mission is to reduce the loss of life and property caused by severe weather and earthquakes through the identification and support of sustained actions that improve society's capacity to adapt to, anticipate, mitigate, withstand and recover from natural disasters. ICLR is achieving its mission through the development and implementation of its programs Open for business, to increase the disaster resilience of small businesses, Designed for safer living, to increase the disaster resilience of homes, and RSVP cities, to increase the disaster resilience of communities. Jon-Erik Lappano, The Co-operators, media@cooperators.ca

urn:contentItem:5CWV-57S1-JBTY-W297-00000-00World Digest2012-01-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:17:34ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. A6World DigestStar wire services

Somalia

Ethiopian forces seize strategic town

Ethiopian troops poured into a strategic town in central Somalia on Saturday, seizing it from Al Shabab militants and opening a new axis of conflict in Somalia.

The loss of Beledweyne, a trading hub near the Ethiopian border, leaves Al Shabab rebels, who once controlled much of the country, spread thin and on the defensive.

Dozens of people appeared to have been killed in the fighting in Beledweyne.

Chile

Israeli tourist held after forest fire

A 23-year-old Israeli tourist has been detained on suspicion of causing a forest fire that has burned more than 11,000 hectares in Chile's Torres de Paine national park, authorities said Saturday.

Regional prosecutor Juan Melendez identified the person as Roter Singer and said the man had acknowledged a part in negligently allowing the fire to start. More than 560 firefighters have been trying to contain the fire, which forced the evacuation of 400 tourists, most of them foreigners.

China

Hu lauds promotion of Kim Jong-un

Chinese President Hu Jintao sent congratulations to North Korea's Kim Jong-un on Saturday on his appointment as supreme military leader.

It was Hu's most direct show of support for the young and untested Kim, who succeeds his father, the late Kim Jong-il.

Earlier in the day, North Korea announced that it had appointed Kim Jong-un as supreme commander of its 1.2 million-strong military, two days after official mourning for Kim Jong-il ended.

Japan

Doomsday cult member turns self in

A member of the doomsday cult behind a deadly Tokyo subway gassing and other crimes has turned himself in to police after 17 years on the run. Tokyo police said Sunday that Makoto Hirata, a 46-year-old member of Aum Shinrikyho, released sarin gas in the Tokyo subway in 1995 in an attack that killed 13 people and injured more than 6,000.

Vatican

Anglicans applying to join Catholic Church

The Vatican is set to launch a new structure Monday that will allow Anglican parishes in the United States, and their married priests, to join the Catholic Church in a small but symbolically potent effort to reunite Protestants and Catholics, who split 500 years ago.

More than 1,300 Anglicans, including 100 Anglican priests, have applied to be part of the new body, essentially a diocese.

Bahrain

Teenager killed

as new clashes erupt

Riot police in Bahrain clashed with reform activists Saturday in one of the most widespread days of protest in the Gulf kingdom for months, firing rubber bullets and filling the air with stinging tear gas.

A gas canister fired from a gun at close range struck a 15-year-old in the chest and killed him, the opposition said. The violence broke out in several towns around the small island nation, and protesters fought back by hurling rocks and firebombs at police.

Crowds have returned to the streets in recent days, pressing for action on recommendations by a government-sponsored inquiry that found evidence of torture.

urn:contentItem:46YB-1000-01G6-B13M-00000-00<published>1998-09-02T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:17:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WESTERN REGIONAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>--B-C Update--</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">((Forest-Fire))</p><p nitf:lede="true">The B-C Forest Service is beefing up the force battling a rapidly moving forest fire northwest of Princeton.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Three helicopters and 45 firefighters are joining fire crews and forestry workers in the woods, along with water bombers in the air.</p><p nitf:lede="true">-BODY- The fire is just five kilometres from homes at Otter Lake and 10 kilometres from the village of Tulameen.</p><p>But no evacuation alert has yet been given.</p><p>Officials have now re-evaluated the size of the blaze at two-thousand hectares, although they expect it to grow to five-thousand within a couple of days. (CIGV,KamNews) ((Forest-Fire-Air))</p><p>A thick haze of smoke from the Tulameen forest fire hangs over much of the Okanagan Valley.</p><p>Officials warn the smoke and falling ash could be a hazard for people with breathing difficulties.</p><p>The air quality was rated as fair late yesterday and the Environment Ministry fears it will get worse today. ((Mill-Fire))</p><p>The world's largest water bombers were called into service at Port Alberni to attack a fire in a sawdust pile.</p><p>A pair of Martin Mars water bombers made more than 20 drops on the fire.</p><p>The three-storey-high pile of wood waste straddles a sawmill operated by MacMillan-Bloedel and a pulp mill owned by Pacifica Papers. (CJAV, A.Valley Times) ((Runaway-Murder))</p><p>The Crown may seek a dangerous-offender declaration for convicted killer Terry Arnold.</p><p>The 36-year-old man pleaded guilty yesterday in Penticton court to a charge of manslaughter.</p><p>Arnold admitting raping a teenage runaway and smashing in her head with a rock seven years ago.</p><p>He was convicted previously of five sexual assaults and several assaults. (Pent Herald) ((Temple-Expenses))</p><p>Vancouver police have sent Canada's largest Sikh temple 27-thousand dollars for extra policing costs.</p><p>But Constable Anne Drennan says the fee doesn't cover all the costs of maintaining a police presence at the Ross Street temple during the fight over tables and chairs.</p><p>The bill will be discussed at the next executive meeting of the temple society. (Vcr Sun) ((Lawyer-Complaints))</p><p>The Law Society of B-C received a record number of complaints last year against lawyers.</p><p>Almost 15-hundred people griped to the society, up more than 100 from the previous year.</p><p>About one in 10 complaints were sent to the discipline committee, which took action in 215 cases. (Vcr Sun) ((WCB-Forestry))</p><p>The Workers' Compensation Board has wiped out savings from a provincial cut in fees to harvest timber.</p><p>Northwood executive C-T Hazelwood says the board's changes to off-road weight restrictions will cost forest companies more than three dollars per cubic metre.</p><p>Earlier this year, the N-D-P government reduced stumpage fees by three-dollars-and-50-cents a cubic metre. (PGeo Citizen) ((Projectionists-Union))</p><p>The B-C Projectionists Union is bracing for the worst after a new proposal by movie theatre chains.</p><p>Union president Damon Faulkner says the employer is demanding the "mother-of-all clawbacks" -- layoffs to 50 per cent of the 66 members and 50-per-cent pay cuts for the rest.</p><p>He says Famous Players and Cineplex are trying to bust the union, which returns to mediation later today. (CNW) ---</p><p>(B-C Update by Don Ramsden)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier (CJCB,CBC-s) (NS-Lost-Found)</p><p>A police tracking dog helped locate five people missing in the Digby, Nova Scotia area.</p><p>Four children accompanied by an adult failed to return from a walk down a woods road yesterday afternoon.</p><p>Last evening, the Clare Search and Rescue team was called in to assist the R-C-M-P.</p><p>Around 10 p.m., the dog led the five people, all in good shape, safely out of the woods. (BN) (NB-Highway Closure)</p><p>A section of the Trans-Canada Highway outside Fredericton has been closed since early this morning.</p><p>A transport truck overturned shortly after 2 a.m., and the cleanup continues.</p><p>Fredericton police closed the Trans-Canada between the Vanier Highway turnoff and the Princess Margaret Bridge.</p><p>The truck driver suffered undetermined injuries and was taken to Fredericton's Chalmers Hospital. (CIHI) (PEI-Fatal)</p><p>The investigation is underway into a fatal farm accident on Prince Edward Island.</p><p>A 55-year-old man died in Souris in an accident involving a cultivator.</p><p>His body was found yesterday afternoon, beneath the equipment.</p><p>Police say an autopsy has yet to be carried out. (CFCY) (Nfld-Forest-Fire)</p><p>Close to two-hundred people remain actively involved in fighting a forest fire outside Badger, Newfoundland.</p><p>The fire is still out of control, but not threatening the community.</p><p>Duty-officer Gerald Fleming says there's been a slight reprieve, with overcast skies and humid weather.</p><p>He says crews are attending to hot spots along the edge of the forest fire. (VOCM) (NB-Layoffs)</p><p>Nineteen southwestern New Brunswick road workers found out this week that their jobs as casual employees had been cut.</p><p>All the layoffs are in the riding of the former transportation minister Sheldon Lee.</p><p>Margaret Ann Blaney is the new minister and denies accusations of partisan politics.</p><p>She says the layoffs are taking place because of changed government priorities. (ATV)</p><p>(Atlantic Update by Jim Crichton)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:58SD-CMG1-JBVR-329B-00000-00Top Atlantic News2013-06-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:17:33ZLexisNexisADVISORIES,ATLANTICTop Atlantic NewsTop Atlantic NewsThe Canadian Press

Here are the Top Atlantic News stories from The Canadian Press as of 4 p.m. AT. All times are local unless otherwise stated. Coverage plans are included when available. Entries are subject to change as news develops. This advisory replaces The Canadian Press News Budget.

Contact the Atlantic News Desk at (902) 422-8496 (Ext. 225) if you have any questions.

___

IN THE NEWS:

No new talks planned between Nova Scotia paramedics, company

NS-Paramedics-Dispute

HALIFAX - The company representing hundreds of paramedics in Nova Scotia says it has met with the union and no new talks are planned ahead of a potential strike next week. Stacey Brown, a spokeswoman with Emergency Medical Care Inc., says officials with the company and Local 727 of the International Union of Operating Engineers returned to the table today with a conciliator. Moved Atlantic.

___

Western Labrador forest fire prompts precautionary evacuation notice in Wabush

NL-Labrador-Fire

WABUSH, N.L. - A fire official in western Labrador says a fourth water bomber and additional ground help will be brought in to battle a forest fire that is burning closer to the town of Wabush. Chuck Porter of the Department of Natural Resources says the southwestern flank of the fire edged towards Wabush on Thursday and is now burning about five kilometres away. Moved Atlantic.

__

Nova Scotia's Strait school board budget includes teacher and staff cuts

NS-School-Budget

PORT HASTINGS, N.S. - The budget for Nova Scotia's Strait Regional School Board includes teaching and staff reductions. Board members approved a budget of more than $82.6 million for 2013-2014 at a special meeting Thursday. Moved Atlantic.

___

Chairman of Nova Scotia tourism group asked to resign over political ties

NS-Tourism-Conflict

YARMOUTH, N.S. - Some municipal councillors in Yarmouth, N.S., are calling for the chairman of a regional tourism association to step down because of his political affiliations. John Cunningham serves as a councillor in the neighbouring Municipality of the District of Yarmouth and is also running for the Progressive Conservatives in the next provincial election. Moved Atlantic. AUDIO.

___

Newfoundland and Labrador's Liberal leadership race gets second candidate

NL-Liberal-Leadership

CORNER BROOK, N.L. - A Liberal member of the Newfoundland and Labrador legislature is the second person to join the run for the party's leadership. Jim Bennett officially announced his candidacy today in Corner Brook.

___

COMING SATURDAY:

HALIFAX - Volunteer Peter L'Esperance to launch hand-built dory which he will row over 150 nautical miles to raise funds and awareness for Nova Scotia Nature Trust. (1:30 p.m. at Maritime Museum of the Atlantic, 1675 Lower Water St.) VIDEO, AUDIO.

___

COMING SUNDAY:

No end seen for New Brunswick gas protests

NB-Shale-Gas

FREDERICTON - The New Brunswick government is pitching the development of a shale gas industry in the province as a potential economic boom and job creator, but opponents - such as residents of the Elsipogtog First Nation - are strengthening their resolve to block the idea, right at the exploration stage. Since early June, there have been protests while SWN Resources conducts the latest series of seismic testing near Elsipgtog, north of Moncton. Chief Arren Sock is calling for an immediate moratorium on shale gas exploration in the province and says his people have an obligation to protect the land and water. Moves National. AUDIO.

___

COMING MONDAY:

Better lobster trap release date clawed back

NS-Lobster-Trap

UNDATED - The need for more testing has delayed the release of a new tool designed to help Atlantic lobster fishermen cut down on costly trap-checking trips. The Bait Savour - a time-delayed bait release box designed to fit inside a lobster trap - is set to hit the market for the winter season, one year after its anticipated release date. Moves National. PHOTO. AUDIO.

urn:contentItem:5NSP-N2S1-JDH3-G0G2-00000-00Ontario researchers to study dust for carcinogens after Fort mcmurray fire2017-06-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:17:33ZLexisNexisNEWSOntario researchers to study dust for carcinogens after Fort mcmurray fire

TORONTO - A group of Ontario researchers is travelling to Fort McMurray, Alta., next month to study dust left in homes from the forest fire that ravaged the city last year.

The team's work is among several studies that are being conducted on the health effects of the ferocious blaze that forced more than 80,000 people to flee.

Arthur Chan, an assistant professor of Chemical Engineering and Applied Chemistry at the University of Toronto, said his team has received overwhelming interest from "concerned" homeowners in Fort McMurray who are offering up their places to be tested.

"We hope we don't find anything," Chan said. "But we're looking for heavy metals and also some organic compounds that are potentially carcinogens. We're going to assess those levels and compare to what we know are normal levels in a home in Canada."

Chan and his team are looking to analyze residual ash from the blaze that consumed 2,400 homes after it hit the city last May.

On July 10, Chan and two of his students will head to Fort McMurray and begin collecting samples from homes in the city and nearby Fort McKay First Nation, which wasn't hit by the fire, but winds blew ash its way.

Chan said he was initially hoping to take samples from 40 places, but residents of 220 homes said they'll open doors to the researchers.

"We will try to go to as many places as we can," he said.

"We will pick up a few samples at each place. We'll try to look at areas that are more accessed, like the living room floor, and then other places that are less frequently cleaned, like the tops of doors."

Chan, who has a background in atmospheric chemistry, first got the idea for the study when he read a news article roughly a month after the wildfire began about people preparing to return to their homes. It got him thinking about the long-term effects of the blaze.

When the Canadian Institutes of Health Research, Alberta Innovates and the Canadian Red Cross put out a call for proposals to look at various health effects in the aftermath of the fire, Chan proposed his research, which won approval and funding from the group along with six other studies.

The other projects are looking at issues that range from the health effects of the blaze on first responders, to the mental health needs of children, to food safety.

Chan said his team will collect samples this summer, again in the fall and a final time next winter and will look to publish the results once their analysis is complete.

They'll also have residents fill out surveys to figure out if an insurance company came and cleaned homes, or if people did the task themselves, and will perform an analysis to see if certain measures led to higher or lower levels of contaminants.

urn:contentItem:3W47-19G0-00H1-P3YK-00000-00<published>1998-06-21T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:17:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>CONTEXT; Pg. F1</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Tinderbox Ontario Will this summer be one of the worst forest fire seasons in the history of the province?</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>by Peter Goodspeed TORONTO STAR</nitf:byline><nitf:dateline>SUDBURY</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>THEIR FACES are weathered and chiselled, as rugged as the landscape they struggle to save.</p><p nitf:lede="true">When they emerge from a week's work in the bush, they are dirty, tired and raccoon-eyed from lack of sleep. Their hands are scraped and scabbed.</p><p nitf:lede="true">For the last two months, they have worked as never before.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Ted Toulouse, one of Ontario's elite "initial attack" fire rangers, says this summer may be one of the worst forest fire seasons in Ontario's history.</p><p>A 55-year-old Ojibwa from Massey, Ont., who has fought wildfires in the North for more than 20 years, Toulouse says our forests are drier than they have been for decades.</p><p>A dry fall, a mild winter and near drought conditions in the spring have turned Ontario's bushland into a potential torch.</p><p>"A lot of crews this spring have experienced as many fires as they would in an entire year," Toulouse says. "And we're not even halfway through the season yet.</p><p>"A while back, when some thunderstorms rolled through, we were getting 40 or 50 fires a day from lightning strikes."</p><p>The fires burn and smoulder beneath the moisture-starved forest floor and spring to life days, even weeks, later with a vengeance and violence that shocks even the men and women who serve as guardians of Ontario's woodlands.</p><p>At one point this spring, there were almost 1,000 people battling 200 forest fires in Ontario and back-up crews were flown in from as far away as British Columbia.</p><p>Conditions deteriorated so badly, the provincial government slapped a ban on all open fires in northwestern Ontario, declaring the region from Manitoba to Nipigon and from the U.S. border to the northern community of Pickle Lake under a restricted fire zone.</p><p>There already have been nearly 700 fires in Ontario since April.</p><p>But the driest, most dangerous months of summer are to come.</p><p>"Fire fighting season came a month early," says Toulouse's crew chief, Bob Butler, 39.</p><p>"We knew we were going to have a bad time, because we didn't get anywhere near the snow we usually do, and the little rain we got in the spring came when there was still frost in the ground. It just ran off and didn't sink in.</p><p>"We've had a little rain recently. But that could dry up in five days. If the humidity drops and we get some wind, it will suck the moisture right out of the ground and we'll be back to fighting fires big time."</p><p>When there's smoke drifting on the wind in Ontario's north country, it triggers an immediate response from a huge seasonal army of water bombers, helicopter pilots, initial attack crews, Category 2 sustained-attack or mop-up crews, fire techs, weather techs, assorted forestry officials, caterers and contractors.</p><p>For five months of every year they alone stand on guard over Ontario's boreal forest - a rugged landscape of black and white spruce, jack pine, aspen and white birch that's half the size of Europe.</p><p>It's a wilderness permanently linked to the Canadian identity. But most Canadians ponder its majesty only through dim, fleeting memories of the howl of timber wolves, the splash of beavers or the sad, lonely wail of a loon.</p><p>Ontario's fire rangers see the forest differently. They know its beauty and its bitterness, its power and its poetry. The bush has a charm of its own when it burns.</p><p>While a crew's days are dominated by the snake-hiss of fire and the flower-like flicker of flames, there are nights with orange moons and mornings with red suns.</p><p>There are chilly breakfasts made perfect by bush coffee and afternoons made immortal by the sad, sudden flaring of a towering cathedral pine against a sky bruised by smoke.</p><p>There's heat and hard work and man's primal fascination with fire.</p><p>For the Aztecs or the Vikings, the early Christians, the ancient Egyptians or ash-smeared holy men in India, fire carries its own reverence.</p><p>It is elemental and mystical. Something that surged forth at the beginning of the world and something that will consume it in the end.</p><p>There is something ancient and fundamental about fire.</p><p>It has a soul of its own.</p><p>-------</p><p>"Each fire is different," Butler says. "No fire is the same. You're always ready for a surprise."</p><p>When fire ranger crews get together, their stories have the rough comfort of the bush camp about them. They camouflage casual heroism with modest humour and carefully mix razzing with respect.</p><p>Toulouse slouches on a couch, wearing a battered blue University of Michigan baseball cap and a slow, shy smile. He recalls nearly being burned to death 12 years ago fighting one of Ontario's legendary forest fires - "Red 7."</p><p>"She burnt right into the winter," he says of the 1986 blaze that destroyed more than 83,000 hectares of 100-year-old jack pine (roughly the size of Greater Toronto) near Red Lake, 145 kilometres northeast of Kenora.</p><p>Thousands of rangers from across Canada struggled to contain the fire. But Toulouse especially remembers one afternoon.</p><p>"We were working by a small lake, trying to slow the fire down, when a radio call came in telling us they were going to take us out," he says.</p><p>"They gave us a half hour to pack our stuff and they said that was it. The fire was getting too hot. They were going to take us back to our base camp by helicopter.</p><p>"I had packed my personal gear and was heading toward the helipad, down in a small swamp, when all of a sudden, there was this sound, like some kind of a train coming. It was heading straight for us and after five or 10 minutes we could see flames coming straight across the lake at us."</p><p>"It was torching right toward us. I could see sparks coming across the lake. We were running around trying to put out those sparks with our waterpacks and our hard hats, anything we could get our hands on.</p><p>"We didn't have time to take the tents or any other stuff out," he says with a tinge of regret.</p><p>"The fire just jumped the lake and went right into the tops of the trees. They didn't have time to come and get us (in the helicopters.) So, we got stuck in a clearing that was about 60 feet wide.</p><p>"The flames were all around us . . . Some were three times the height of the trees . . . We had to get right down close to the ground and breathe there," he says calmly, describing a desperate bid to avoid suffocation by gulping in mouthfuls of the thin layer of air that clings to the ground in any forest fire.</p><p>"I was lying there, hugging the ground, thinking of my escape route.</p><p>"I was thinking I might have to get into the lake. For about 10 minutes, the fire raged around us. But it moved on.</p><p>"After a half hour, they came to pick us up. The only thing I had left was my clothes."</p><p>His eyes twinkle with boyish adventure at the memory.</p><p>"The main thing is not to panic," he says. "You just do what you are taught to do."</p><p>-------</p><p>There was a time when fighting forest fires was pick and shovel work.</p><p>A lonely forest ranger in an isolated lookout tower would radio in a fire report and men, sometimes conscripted right off the sidewalk in nearby towns, were rushed to the scene with instructions to cut a fire line around a blaze.</p><p>Times have changed.</p><p>Today, Ontario's fire crews are high-tech foresters who:</p><p>* Track threatening thunderstorms on a province-wide radar grid that can locate every lightning bolt that comes to ground.</p><p>* Have vast computer data banks on a wide range of subjects from fire behaviour to ground moisture.</p><p>* Use sophisticated water bomber aircraft to conduct precision air attacks on fires.</p><p>* Use global positioning satellites in the field to find their way through the bush, and hand-held infra-red scanners to search out smouldering fires underground.</p><p>"We've been able to get to a situation, where we don't get surprised," says natural resources spokesperson Len Munro.</p><p>"The new technology allows us to respond a lot more quickly and to know exactly what sort of fire behaviour we can expect." Every day at 1 p.m., at a series of weather stations across the province, technicians record the temperature, relative humidity, wind speed and direction, and the amount of precipitation in their corner of Ontario over the previous 24 hours.</p><p>The information is plugged into natural resources ministry computers along with weather predictions for the next four days, ground moisture readings and fire behaviour patterns for different types of forest, to produce data on any possible fire threat.</p><p>"We should be able to tell our crews exactly what they can expect," says Bill Droog, a fire intelligence officer at Sudbury's Forest Fire Management Centre.</p><p>"If we get a fire today, we should be able to tell a crew what they are going to see. We should be able to say you can expect to see open flame, flames that are three metres tall or one metre tall, their rate of spread and whether they are going to need air attack."</p><p>Still, some things don't change.</p><p>"One thing is constant, you still need firefighters on the ground with pumps and hose trying to put water on it," Munro says.</p><p>-------</p><p>Along with the dirt and the smoke, there is a unique camaraderie among the fire crews.</p><p>"We like to call ourselves the 'Hallmark Crew,' " jokes crew chief Butler, referring to his three-person squad that includes Toulouse and Christine Jaworski, a former fitness instructor who runs a ceramics business in the off season.</p><p>"When you care enough, you send the best," he chortles.</p><p>The three combined - and that's how they regard themselves, as a team - have spent almost 50 years fighting forest fires.</p><p>"We're trained. We're experienced. We know what situations not to get into out there," Butler says.</p><p>"As soon as you are dispatched to a fire and you see a plume of smoke, right away you are wondering what sort of fuel it is in. You're looking at the height of the smoke, the colour of the smoke.</p><p>"The colour of the smoke will tell you a lot about the fire sometimes.</p><p>"A black column means there's not a whole lot of moisture. The fire will burn pretty intense.</p><p>"When we fly into a fire, I'll start looking at the topography," he continues. "It's important. If you are dealing with greened-up poplar, full of leaves, it's not going to be burning a whole lot. It will be smouldering away. There will be ground fire. But it's not going to torch up through the trees.</p><p>"If it was spruce or balsam - the coniferous species - it will kick up and start torching. From 10 miles back, you can see the flames in the treetops."</p><p>Once a crew arrives at a fire, the crew chief immediately starts to radio back an assessment of their situation.</p><p>The chief reports on any humans or property in the area, the size of the fire and its rate of spread, the availability of water sources to fight the fire, the need for water bombers or additional fire crews, the topography of the area.</p><p>If a fire is especially hot or threatens to jump out of control, one of the first things a crew does is call for water bombers.</p><p>Ontario has a fleet of specially designed planes that can skim a lake or river in a matter of seconds and suck up 5,900 kilograms of water - which they can then deposit on a fire from a height of only 30 metres.</p><p>"The first couple of drops are crucial," says Jack Cartledge, a senior fire officer with the ministry of natural resources. "You've got to get them in the right place. The first couple of loads calm the fire.</p><p>"If at all possible, you try to pinch it off in flight. Then you look after the flanks.</p><p>"But if the smoke is such that you can't get into the head of a fire, you'll want to drop a few loads at the back end, to knock the smoke down, so you can get at the flame."</p><p>In the meantime, the attack crews prepare their own battle plans.</p><p>They rush to set up their pumps and lay their hose as soon as they land. While Butler is walking through the bush, radioing back his initial assessments, he is also laying down a series of signal flags, telling Jaworski where he wants her to put their hose, so they can attack the fire directly.</p><p>The heat in a fire is intense. The air is full of swirling ash and the flames sound like a constant, heavy rainfall.</p><p>Jaworski's job is to haul 32-kilogram packs of 30-metre lengths of hose through the underbrush to set up the initial attack line. After each length is laid, she has to return to the pump site for another pack.</p><p>"We work as a team," she says. "Everybody does their part. We're like a little family all the time. We watch out for each other. We almost know what the others are thinking.</p><p>"You have to be strong. It's not for everyone. You have to withstand the bugs. You have to be willing to go for days sometimes without being able to wash properly. You have to be able to get along with the men. You have to move at their speed."</p><p>A former fitness club owner and aerobics instructor, 33-year-old Jaworski is also a four-time women's world arm-wrestling champion. She has won the Canadian title seven times.</p><p>"You have to understand, I'm not trying to be a man by doing this job," she says. "I'm doing this job because I like doing it. I love it. We love our jobs. We love being with each other, love saving life, saving values (property), saving the forest."</p><p>"You can really see a sense of accomplishment once it's done," Butler adds. "I worked timber one time, on a tree farm, on a tree study. I can't do it. I can't just sit around and watch trees grow. You know what I mean? It's just not as rewarding.</p><p>"There's an adrenaline rush with fire," he says.</p><p>"It's always there, I guess, or I wouldn't be doing it for so frigging long. It's my 20th year on fires. There's something in the blood that keeps making you come back."</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>CP colour photos: FURY OF THE FLAMES: Flames leap into the sky as forest fires burn last month 120 kilometres northeast of Thunder Bay (main photo) and between Schreiber and Terrace Bay. CP file photo (p.F4) HELP FROM THE AIR: A water bomber, one of a fleet of specially designed planes, lets loose a cloud of vapour to douse a forest fire in Naughton, near Sudbury, last month. Star photo (STEVE RUSSELL) DIRT, SMOKE AND CAMARADERIE: Firefighter Christine Jaworski is a former fitness club owner.</p></caption></nitf:media></graphic></nitf:body.end></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:46YD-70Y0-01G6-B363-00000-00<published>1999-05-03T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:17:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WESTERN REGIONAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>--Prairie Update--</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">(Alta-School-Shooting)</p><p nitf:lede="true">The father of a 17-year-old Taber, Alberta youth shot to death by a gunman last week says he doesn't want his son's death to be in vain.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Reverend Dale Lang told the hundreds of people who had crowded into a school gymnasium that there had to be a change at the high school where Jason Lang lost his life.</p><p nitf:lede="true">-BODY- He pleaded with students to be more accepting of people who are different, instead of ridiculing them.</p><p>There are reports the teen gunman who started shooting up the school had been pulled out of classes because he was picked on. (BN) (Gas-Vandalism-Security)</p><p>Security has been stepped up at the court house in Grande Prairie, Alberta as two men go on trial in a gas well vandalism conspiracy case.</p><p>Defense lawyers are wearing bullet-proof vests outside the court room.</p><p>Lawyer Richard Secord (see-cord) says he's nervous after Wiebo Ludwig's (wee-bow lood-wig) van was blown up a couple of weeks ago outside an Edmonton hotel.</p><p>Metal detectors have also been installed for the preliminary hearing, which is expected to last three weeks. (CFGP, CJXX) (Mba-Forest-Fire)</p><p>The Manitoba government is under fire for not providing enough equipment to a community threatened by a forest fire.</p><p>Derek Bushie of the Hollow Water First Nation says water bombers didn't arrive until this morning.</p><p>He thinks they should have been called out earlier.</p><p>Six-hundred people have been evacuated from three communities in east-central Manitoba since the weekend. (BN) (Mba-Fire-Out)</p><p>Another fire raging in Manitoba is under control.</p><p>The blaze, near Piney in south eastern Manitoba closed a highway yesterday.</p><p>It was re-opened this morning.</p><p>Police say it appears the fire started at the town's garbage dump.</p><p>The forest fire has burned 700 hectares. (CHSM) (Milgaard-Compensation)</p><p>There could be a compensation deal in the works for a Saskatchewan man who wrongly spent time in prison.</p><p>David Milgaard's lawyer says a meeting was held with a negotiator over the weekend in Montreal, and "progress is being made."</p><p>Joyce Milgaard was set to meet with the province's justice minister tomorrow.</p><p>She was going to pitch a tent in front of the Saskatchewan legislature if the meeting didn't go very well. (BN)</p><p>(Prairie Update by Lisa Arrowsmith)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5PHF-FV51-JBVR-31P3-00000-00Judge decries 'mob mentality:' Suspended sentence for woman who faked cancer2017-09-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:17:34ZLexisNexisNATIONALJudge decries 'mob mentality:' Suspended sentence for woman who faked cancerSuspended sentence for Calgary cancer fakerBill GravelandThe Canadian Press

CALGARY - A judge who on Monday spared a woman jail time for pretending to have cancer and claiming to be a wildfire evacuee was highly critical of the general public's "mob mentality" toward her.

Judge Anne Brown handed Jennifer Halford a two-year suspended sentence. Both the Crown and the defence had asked for leniency.

Halford, who is 35, entered guilty pleas last year on seven counts of fraud. She had claimed that she had aggressive breast cancer and that she and her family had lost everything in the 2016 Fort McMurray forest fire in northern Alberta.

She received donations that included gift cards, food, clothing, babysitting services and beauty treatments.

The Crown said Halford was going through depression when she made the claims.

"Some of the things that happened to you after your crimes were highly publicized were absolutely shocking," Brown said as Halford sobbed in the prisoner's box.

"They are the most horrible manifestations of mob mentality. A mob doesn't have a brain and nor does it have a compassionate heart." the judge said.

"What happens when a mob acts is the behaviour is driven by fear and anger. You've been subjected to some of that and it's a shocking and horrible thing."

Halford, who declined an opportunity to address the court, blurted out at that point: "It's scary."

Prosecutor Jason Wuttunee told court that Halford's motivation was not greed but a way to gain the attention and support she felt she needed.

He said Halford was sexually abused as a child, had to care for a disabled brother, took in several foster children over the years and lost her five-year-old daughter to cancer in 2011.

"There is much to be said about ... the woman who has experienced a significant amount of tragedy in her life, a woman who was overwhelmed and unable to cope with circumstances," said Wuttunee.

"She was obviously not well when she acted in what the public would see as a very outrageous manner."

Outside court, the prosecutor applauded the judge for accepting the joint submission that suggested Halford had already suffered.

"Miss Halford had reported that she had suffered from death threats and other stigmas as a result of committing the crimes," he said.

"Miss Halford was publicly shamed and disgraced as a result of doing what she has done and ... what the judge is trying to say is mob mentality is not justified."

Halford was ordered to pay restitution to her victims, to perform 100 hours of community service, to stay away from social media and to seek counselling.

"She's actually made a number of steps in the past year. She's seen some counsellors. She's seen her family doctor," said defence lawyer Michelle Parhar.

"She's taking some courses and has gone back to school and all of that is going to lend itself to how she deals with this in the next two years."

urn:contentItem:46YD-7360-01G6-B1GN-00000-00<published>1999-05-29T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:17:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>GENERAL AND NATIONAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>--Ninth NewsWatch--</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">(Mba-Forest Fire) (Audio: 059)</p><p nitf:lede="true">A forest fire is still keeping about 12-hundred people from their homes in Cross Lake.</p><p nitf:lede="true">They fled the northern Manitoba community yesterday.</p><p nitf:lede="true">It's not known how long they'll have to stay away.</p><p>-BODY- Officials are hoping the rain in the forecast should help the 100 or so firefighters and five water bombers battling the blaze. (9) (Sask-Forest Fire)</p><p>Crews are busy working on the hot spots of an 800-hectare fire burning near La Ronge, Saskatchewan.</p><p>Officials say the blaze is out of control, but it's not moving or getting any bigger.</p><p>The fire has destroyed a number of homes on the community's outskirts. (9) (Alta-Forest Fires)</p><p>Alberta firefighters are also busy with several serious blazes this weekend.</p><p>Two fires are burning outside Fort McMurray. (9) (Space Shuttle) (Audio: 072)</p><p>One adventure down, and on to the next.</p><p>"Discovery'' astronauts docked the shuttle flawlessly with the new International Space Station today.</p><p>Next, two crew members will take a late-night spacewalk.</p><p>The six-hour space walk will be guided in part by Montrealer Julie Payette. (9) (Kosovo-NATO)</p><p>NATO planes took aim again on power stations.</p><p>Parts of Serbia are in the dark, including the capital Belgrade.</p><p>In recent days, NATO has been destroying major Serbian power installations and distribution facilities. (9) (Kosovar-Refugees)</p><p>Thirteen Kosovar refugees are getting ready to start a new life near Calgary.</p><p>They've left C-F-B Aldershot, near Kentville, Nova Scotia.</p><p>They'll take a flight from Halifax to Alberta tonight.</p><p>Sponsoring groups will meet the refugees in Cochrane, Alberta tomorrow. (9) (Austria-Accident)</p><p>Intense heat and fallen chunks of concrete are hampering rescuers at an Austrian highway tunnel.</p><p>A truck crashed into a car and set off explosions and a massive fire.</p><p>At least one person was killed and several others are feared dead. (9) (JFK-Coffin Mystery)</p><p>It was a mystery for three and a-half decades.</p><p>Where was the bronze casket used to transport U-S President John F. Kennedy's body from Dallas to Washington?</p><p>The riddle has been answered.</p><p>The coffin is at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean.</p><p>It was dropped in a dumping area for old weapons and ammunition two years after Kennedy was assassinated in 1963. (9) ---</p><p>(NewsWatch by Geri Smith)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4678-45C0-01G6-90PP-00000-00<published>2002-07-06T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:17:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>GENERAL AND NATIONAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Forest fires continue to rage in northern Quebec, and forecast is no help</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">MONTREAL (CP) _ A forest fire raging in the northern Quebec region of Nemiscau, near James Bay, gained momentum Saturday and the resulting smoke from it and 45 blazes in the province spread as far south as New York state.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The Nemiscau fire has eaten up 600 square kilometres of forest since it began July 2, and all access roads to the area have been closed to through traffic. The fire is moving at a pace of 50 metres per minute.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>The nearby village of Nemaska, home to about 500 Cree aboriginals, has been completely evacuated. An offshoot of the Nemiscau fire had reached to within 800 metres of the village Friday, but the fire had retreated to two kilometres away by Saturday evening.</p><p>Smoke was so dense the provincial forest fire protection service cannot fly its planes through the region.</p><p>Visibility in Toronto was reduced to three kilometres Saturday, prompting many calls to Environment Canada looking for an explanation.</p><p> I had someone call me to say it (the smell) was a welcome relief from the garbage,'' said Alain Boisvert, a forecaster at Environment Canada, referring to a city strike now in its second week that has resulted in garbage piling up all over the city.</p><p>Steve McLaughlin, a meteorologist with the U.S. National Weather Service in Albany, N.Y., said a patch of smoke about 300 kilometres in diameter, hovered Saturday over the cities of Watertown, Syracuse and Binghamton before heading south toward New York City.</p><p> The skies will be very milky, very hazy, across New York and southern New England,'' he said. It may seem like it's getting cloudy, but all the milkiness in the sky is smoke.''</p><p>The Quebec forest fire protection service considers the situation critical, with no rain expected until at least until Tuesday.</p><p> There are many, many fires that are out of control, about 11 in all,'' said spokeswoman Chantal Drapeau. The forecast is calling for nice weather through Tuesday, maybe even Wednesday, and they are even calling for stronger winds as of Sunday. So none of this helps us.''</p><p>The 11 fires that are considered out of control are all north of Lac St-Jean, between the Manouane Reservoir and Lac Albanel, Drapeau said.</p><p>On Friday, 500,000 Quebecers had their electricity cut when the Nemiscau fire came too close to a Hydro-Quebec electrical tower, forcing the utility to shut it down and re-route power from other areas.</p><p>There is a fire ban almost everywhere in the province north of the St. Lawrence River.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5S9X-W211-JDH3-G01T-00000-00Phase two of Harrison group's anti-quarry initiative underway2018-05-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:17:33ZLexisNexisNEWSPhase two of Harrison group's anti-quarry initiative underway

With ongoing municipal support and provincial media coverage, the Friends of Agassiz and Harrison Hot Springs group continues to push ahead in its quest to stop mining activity one kilometre from the entrance to the local tourism municipality.

The future of the land

Construction is already underway near the site of the proposed aggregate quarry on District of Kent land.

While developer TC Merritt Valley Farms might use blasted materials from the quarry for other projects, the reclamation proposal listed in the application is for a residential subdivision. In order to develop the land properly for housing, the company first needs approval from the Ministry of Energy, Mines and Petroleum Resources.

It's unclear how long the land would be blasted before being developed, but the application lists December 2030 as the proposed end date for mining activities.

READ: Hundreds of Agassiz, Harrison residents gather to oppose quarry application

The District of Kent has stayed silent regarding its stance on the project, telling The Observer that if or when the municipality receives a rezoning application for the land, it will need to be impartial.

"We cannot talk about plans pertaining to the subdivision until, if and when an application was made for one, as that would involve a public hearing and we cannot be seen to be taking a position without all the facts," said Mayor John Van Laerhoven at the district's council meeting April 23.

The mayor also presented the district's referral response to the Ministry of Energy Mines and Petroleum Resources, listing a number of proposed conditions for the ministry's approval, including a dust control plan, provincial Water Sustainability Act approval and an engineering review, to name a few.

Phase II

The local opposition group recently started "phase two" of its letter-writing campaign, sending emails and letters to elected officials and agencies, including the Ministry of Tourism and the Ministry of Transportation and Infrastructure.

The group's campaign leaders create letter formats for group members to fill out and send to the province and other stakeholders - with hopes that strength in numbers will give them a fighting chance to stop the operation from going any further.

A letter to Minister of Tourism, Arts and Culture Lisa Beare focuses specifically on risks to the municipality's top industry.

"Instead of tourists seeing beautiful mountains and agricultural properties when travelling into Harrison, they will see an open quarry mine that visually disfigures our beautiful views," it reads.

It isn't just the sights that have residents and business owners concerned. It's also the sounds.

"Harrison Lake and local mountains magnify noises and echo throughout our valley. It is only a short distance from the proposed mine to Harrison Hot Springs and I have concerns that the noise from blasting at this location will travel to the center of our town and severely impact the peace and tranquility which both residents and tourists enjoy."

A letter addressed to the Minister of Transportation and Infrastructure Claire Trevena expresses the group's concerns about the quarry's location - 430 metres off of Highway 9, a narrow two-way road and the only route in and out of the Village.

"Hot Springs Road provides the local residents, tourists and visitors the only evacuation route in the event of a natural catastrophe such as forest fire, flooding or an earthquake," the letter reads.

READ: Proper engagement needed for quarry development: expert

Large numbers of the concerned citizens have also sent letters to the minister of agriculture and the Agricultural Land Commission.

Committee member Harold Bruins said despite the lack of news from the province, the group remains motivated.

"We've kept up the momentum....We're working now on phase three, which we hope to launch by Monday," he said. "We have definitely got the ear of the people in Victoria. They're listening to us."

urn:contentItem:49C3-9JN0-00RG-W2FR-00000-00<published>2003-08-22T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:17:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>DOMESTIC NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Molson Canadian cancels House Party in Kelowna and donates $20,000 to the Red Cross;<br/> Funds to Aid Red Cross Forest Fire Relief Fund</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>KELOWNA, BC, Aug. 22</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Due to the ongoing unfortunate circumstances <br/>impacting Kelowna, Molson has cancelled its fifth annual Molson Canadian House <br/>Party which was to take place at Kelowna's Skyreach Place on Saturday, August <br/>23. <br/>    In an effort to assist families affected by the forest fires that are <br/>raging in the southern Interior, Molson had originally planned to encourage <br/>concert-goers to donate money to the Red Cross. Molson would have matched all <br/>money raised at the Molson Canadian House Party, but due to the concert <br/>cancellation, Molson announced today that it will now donate $20,000 to the <br/>Red Cross. <br/>    "Molson has a long history of involvement in communities across B.C. <br/>through our charitable programs and sports and entertainment sponsorships. We <br/>feel it is vital to support the communities and families affected by these <br/>fires by contributing to the Red Cross' fire relief efforts," said Sean <br/>Lanigan, BC Sales Director, Molson. "We're proud to share responsibility for <br/>helping our communities during this challenging time." <br/>    "We are extremely pleased with Molson's generosity," said Colleen <br/>Lavender, Red Cross Spokesperson. "We have no doubt that this donation will <br/>make a difference to families who have been impacted by the fires." <br/>    Canadian Red Cross is appealing for $1 million to provide recovery <br/>assistance to residents affected by this disaster. Canadian Red Cross and its <br/>disaster partners have already provided more than $375,000 in assistance to <br/>those affected by the fires. Canadians who wish to donate can call, toll-free, <br/>1-800-418-1111.</p><p>  Molson Inc. (TSX: MOL.A) is one of the world's largest brewers of quality <br/>beer with operations in Canada, Brazil and the United States. A global brewer <br/>with $3.5 billion in gross annual sales, Molson traces its roots back to 1786 <br/>making it North America's oldest beer brand. Committed to brewing excellence, <br/>Molson combines the finest natural ingredients with the highest standards of <br/>quality to produce an award-winning portfolio of beers including urn:contentItem:5G97-52X1-JCMN-Y1M2-00000-00Iconic 1,000-year-old 'Elaho Giant' Douglas fir saved from fire2015-06-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:17:33ZLexisNexisIconic 1,000-year-old 'Elaho Giant' Douglas fir saved from fire

Jun 25, 2015( Digital Journal: http://www.digitaljournal.com Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Roots blackened, the mighty Elaho Giant, Canada's third largest tree, has survived a devastating wildfire, thanks to quick thinking by firefighters, who worked tirelessly to "cool hotspots" near the huge tree's roots.<nl/> Thought to be the world's thickest Douglas fir, the tree's base is blackened, but still sprouting green needles, the District of Squamish said in a statement, according to The Huffington Post.[1]<nl/>

<nl/> <nl/><nl/>Fortunately, Douglas firs have thick, protective bark and this makes the tree resistant to fire damage, and the Elaho Giant has almost certainly seen numerous fires in its day.<nl/> It's thought that lightning sparked the 700-hectare (1,729 acre) fire in the Elaho Valley[2] over the weekend, but by Wednesday, firefighters reported that the blaze was 40 percent contained.<nl/> When crews arrived on the scene, the Giant was surrounded by ash and "danger trees," which earned this name because their root systems have been burned off, putting them at imminent risk of falling, The National Post [3]reports.<nl/> To access the tree, fire crews had to trek over steep and treacherous terrain to tamp the hotspots at the base of the giant's roots, said Fire Information officer Donna MacPherson on Monday.<nl/> On Tuesday, the District of Squamish was able to confidently announce to a worried public that the great tree had been saved.<nl/> Activists from the Wilderness Committee discovered the Giant while in the midst of a mid-1990s campaign to halt a road planned for the valley, said Joe Foy, the committee's national campaign director.<nl/> "As they were flagging a trail route, they ran into this gigantic Douglas fir tree," he said.<nl/> Intense protests against old-growth logging operations in the Upper Elaho Valley, which is the tree's home helped position the Giant as a major focal point for environmentalists, The National Post reported.<nl/> Located at the edge of a clearcut, this magnificent Douglas fir was given a reprieve in 1995.<nl/> Fortunately, now much of the Upper Elaho Valley is a protected area.<nl/> The top of this enormous tree has broken off, leaving it at only 50 meters tall. Rough estimates place its age at more than 1,000 years. However, no one has been able to obtain a core sample to confirm this, Foy said.<nl/> Core samples have been obtained from other nearby Douglas firs and it appears they may be as old as 1,300 years, meaning that the firs of the Elaho valley may be the oldest of their species on the planet, The National Post reports.<nl/> This stately giant has a circumference of nine meters (29 feet), and is 2.7 meters (8.8 feet) in diameter. It's circumference is large enough, in fact, that it would take five adult men holding hands to surround it, The Vancouver Sun[4] reports.<nl/> British Columbia is truly a land of giant trees, and the world's largest Douglas fir is immense. With a circumference of 12 meters (just over 39 feet), the Red Creek Fir[5] is located in Port Renfrew.<nl/> The Elaho Giant sits like a king among younger trees, and it's very likely that this isn't the first time the tree has cheated death by forest fire.<nl/> "It's a spectacular Douglas fir tree, but Douglas fir trees are known for resisting some level of fire," Foy said. "That's what their bark is all about.<nl/> At 1,835 years old, a yellow cedar on B.C.'s Sunshine Coast is the oldest tree ever identified in a Canadian forest. Tragically that tree was felled in a 1980 clearcut, however its stump was discovered by activists in 1993, The National Post reports. This tree was a sapling in the year 145, when the Roman Empire was in power over what would become Great Britain.<nl/> Scores of people — including 112 firefighters and a 13-person incident management team have been fighting the blaze, along with five helicopters and two pieces of heavy equipment.<nl/> The forecast, however, calls for more hot, dry weather over the next week, and officials warn that the fire may continue to grow.<nl/> [ 1]: http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2015/06/24/1000-year-old-tree-fire-bc-elaho_n_7656852.html [ 2]:   http://www.vancouversun.com/news/Hikers+warned+stay+away+from+Elaho+Valley+forest+fire+burns/11154087/story.html [ 3]:   http://news.nationalpost.com/news/canada/elaho-giant-1000-year-old-douglas-fir-saved-by-quick-action-of-b-c-fire-crews [ 4]:   http://www.vancouversun.com/news/year+Elaho+Giant+tree+danger+from+wildfire+with+video/11157107/story.html [ 5]:   http://www.portrenfrew.com/redfir.htm

urn:contentItem:5CNW-86W1-DY9S-T51S-00000-00Firefighters in West Kelowna, B.C., hit brush fire; no evacuation alerts, orders2014-07-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:17:33ZLexisNexisWEATHER,PRAIRIES/BCFirefighters in West Kelowna, B.C., hit brush fire; no evacuation alerts, ordersWest Kelowna, B.C., fire crews battle brush blazeThe Canadian Press

WEST KELOWNA, B.C. - On the ground and from the air, firefighters spent Tuesday evening battling a five-hectare brush fire near a residential area in the Okanagan community of West Kelowna, B.C.

The flames, believed to be human caused, broke out on the east slope of Mt. Boucherie, said Melissa Klassen, of the Wildfire Management Branch.

But thanks to the efforts of West Kelowna Fire Rescue as well as two air tankers, a helicopter and bird dog, the blaze was smouldering by the early evening, she said.

Klassen said firefighters also dropped retardant on three sides of the fire, and a road acted as a natural barrier on the remaining side.

"Structures are in the area but none are immediately threatened at the time," she said.

Central Okanagan Emergency Operations reports no evacuation alerts or orders have been issued, an emergency operations' centre is now running and police are redirecting traffic away from a local road.

Emergency officials are also asking boaters on nearby Okanagan Lake to stay out of the way of helicopters that are filling buckets with water.

There have been several fires in that area of the Okanagan Valley area over the years, including a 2003 forest fire that burned into Kelowna and consumed 238 homes.

The Wildfire Management Branch reports there are a few dozen fires larger than 10 hectares that are still burning in the province or in the mop-up stages.

urn:contentItem:5PDM-5W71-JDH3-G48J-00000-00Liberals committed to green NAFTA2017-09-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:17:34ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. A6Liberals committed to green NAFTAMcKenna 'done' with 'ridiculous' Tory talk on environmentMia RabsonThe Canadian Press

Canada's push to get climate change action included in a revamped North American Free Trade Agreement is turning into a heated domestic dispute, just as it makes its debut at the official negotiating table.

The NAFTA schedule obtained by The Canadian Press showed the environment was on the schedule for seven hours of NAFTA talks in Mexico City Monday, and another seven hours on Tuesday.

It could be one of the more contentious chapters, as significant differences of opinion about the environment exist between the Liberal government of Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and U.S. President Donald Trump.

Those differences largely exist domestically as well and were being played out in social media over the Labour Day weekend.

Environment Minister Catherine McKenna launched an angry missive at Conservative Foreign Affairs critic Erin O'Toole on Sunday, for suggesting the environment was a mere "trinket" better left to the sidelines in order to protect Canada's economic well-being.

She was responding to comments O'Toole made to The Canadian Press in which he accused the government's push for environmental protections, Indigenous rights and gender equality as "virtue signalling" as part of the image-building machinery around the prime minister.

"And so done with ridiculous language from #CPC like 'virtue signalling,'" McKenna tweeted. "We will continue to stand up for Canadian values at home & abroad."

She wrote a lengthy response on Facebook noting it was his party under prime minister Brian Mulroney that first included the environment in a Canadian trade deal with NAFTA's parallel environment agreement.

"We are currently witnessing the largest forest fire in British Columbia's history, the Atlantic Ocean recording record temperatures, and the second flood of the century in 12 months in Windsor," McKenna wrote. "And the conservatives are still saying that the environment and the economy can be separated! Climate change is real and environmental protection is essential. It is time for the conservatives to understand the message."

A spokesperson for Trudeau said McKenna's Facebook post was the official government response to O'Toole.

At the NAFTA table, Canada and the United States both want the environment agreement to be pulled into the main NAFTA papers rather than existing as a side deal.

They also both want provisions to prevent NAFTA countries from loosening environmental restrictions as a way to attract investment.

Where they differ, however, is on climate change. While the Americans stated one of their NAFTA goals was to include a requirement for countries to live up to their obligations under multilateral agreements, the U.S. is in the process of withdrawing from the biggest of those agreements on climate change, the Paris accord.

Trump has previously referred to climate change as a "hoax" and has started undoing policies of the former administration of Barack Obama, such as fossil fuel production restrictions, which he says have hurt the U.S. economy.

Canada would like a new NAFTA to specifically reference climate change and prioritize measures to help combat it.

urn:contentItem:5G71-VK11-JDV5-F0HR-00000-00Uplifting conclusion to parachute fail2015-06-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:17:33ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Uplifting conclusion to parachute fail

Witnesses in the vicinity of highway 17 recently were aghast to spot a parachute spiralling out of control and plummeting to the ground at an escalated speed.

Many grabbed their cellphones and called 911. Ambulances scurried to the scene, at a home west of TSC Store.

Turns out that is all it was; a parachute.

"It was an empty parachute with nobody in it," said Trevor Fitzpatrick, chief instructor at Mile High Parachuting.

He said the parachutist performed a "cut away" when they discovered a "small issue" with the parachute. A backup one was deployed and the person made a save landing no more than 10 feet from the target.

The first parachute was caught by the wind and landed on a residential lawn at about 2:30 p.m. It was picked up by a resident and return to the company that operates from the Arnprior Airport.

The procedure is not employed often. It was the first time this year, and might not have been used at all last year.

Fitzpatrick said Mile High has been in operation since 1993 and has 1,000s of jumps every year. No one has died, and no parachutes have landed on the highway.

It's part of the cellphone world we live in. Farmers often complain of firefighters showing up at their door during a controlled backyard burn. People driving along a country road spot smoke rising and they call in a forest fire.

Many farmers now know to contact the fire department beforehand, just to head off the financial and time costs associated with firefighters and trucks showing up on scene.

FUNDRAISING EVENT

That day in Arnprior, Sunday, June 7, saw some 40 people parachuting for a cause. They raised more than $12,000 for Lanark County Interval House. All had a connection to the women's shelter and ranged from ages 18 to 65, said Fitzpatrick.

"It was great. Over 30 were first timers and there was a barbecue afterward."
