urn:contentItem:5S7K-XVK1-JC4Y-02PS-00000-00Blessed to have had a strong, loving and gracious mother2018-05-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:17:33ZLexisNexisEDITORIALPg. A4Blessed to have had a strong, loving and gracious mother

This year on Mother's Day, I will be hailing in some wonderment, the life of Marjorie Hogg Burns, my mother.

Her life of 85 years, spent entirely in the District of Temiskaming, a three-hour drive north of North Bay, she would think unremarkable. But my perspective and the facts show otherwise.

Her father, Samuel Hogg, from Cobourg, had homesteaded to the north in 1897. Arriving in New Liskeard and finding all the Crown lands along the Wabi River recorded, he went 12 miles away to locate his farm.

He walked to the foot of Lake Temiskaming to a mill for lumber, built a punt and slept under it, while trees were being cut and a little shack built.

In June, 1898, Sam Hogg returned to Baltimore, Ontario for his bride, Alberta Mitchell, who was welcomed to the north in a canoe decorated with wild flowers. She wrote at the time," For my first few years in this new land, the torture suffered by mosquitoes and black flies was my most trying experience."

A first child, Alexander, was born in 1900, and my mother in 1904. Samuel Hogg was elected first reeve of the Township.

There are gaps in my mother's story. I regret not asking her more fully. I know she won a public speaking contest in 1917 from the Canada Victory Loan Competition. I have the medal; she was 13 years old. Then she went to North Bay Normal School at age 17, and the next year was teaching in a one-room school house, Whitewood Grove in Hilliard Township. She was 18.

The dreadful Haileybury forest fire occurred in 1922, over two days. There were 54 deaths. It swept through 650 square miles.

The curator of the Haileybury museum wrote to me in 2004: "Your mother, Miss Marjorie Hogg, protected her schoolchildren by shepherding them under a small bridge and keeping soaked blankets around them. When the smoke and fire seemed to be advancing rapidly, she had made some trunk calls to parents. "Wait, I'll run outside and look" said one. She came back to the phone and had time to say, 'Don't dismiss them; we are cut off by the fire.' The line went dead. If Miss Hogg had dismissed the class, very few would have reached home alive."

Her parents' home in New Liskeard was destroyed and within it, her hope chest full of embroidered items, her trousseau.

Twelve years later, she was principal of Kirkland West School in Kirkland Lake. A young Catholic lawyer from Almonte, Ontario arrived in town.

My mother had been courted by many young mining engineers who had come in the gold rush, but she chose my father. The religious tensions, Catholic/ Protestant of the time, prevented them, now in their 30s, from marrying there, so they went to Toronto. My father seems to have established the religion of the household, so we four kids were raised Catholic. My mother, the onetime Methodist organist, told me once she never had put her "whole weight" down in that church.

She was a cultured woman, who played the piano for memorable family sing-songs; a great cook, whose specialty was cheese straws, and a legendary bridge player.

She encouraged me to read, play sports and run for student council. She suffered a long, undiagnosed illness stoically. Into our home came her elderly, hearing-impaired mother.

Next year, I hope to honour my mother and my Scots Presbyterian heritage, by joining Rev. Bob Root on a pilgrimage to the Church of Scotland mission on the island of Iona in the Hebrides.

We are blessed when we have had strong, loving and gracious mothers.

Rosemary Ganley is a writer, teacher and activist. Reach her at rganley2016 @gmail.com

urn:contentItem:7W8X-4DR1-2PP6-R1FN-00000-00Olympic fire plan: Turn on snow2009-08-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:17:33ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. A12Olympic fire plan: Turn on snowSunny DhillonTHE CANADIAN PRESSWHISTLER, B.C.

Fire officials say a blaze on a B.C. Olympic mountain is much smaller than originally feared but, just in case, there's a backup plan if the winds suddenly shift and threaten 2010 Games venues.

They'll turn on the snowmaking equipment.

"On the alpine venue, we're fortunate enough to have a sprinkler system, more or less, with the snowmaking capacity we have in that zone, so we have reservoirs and the ability to pump water into those zones," said Doug Forseth, vice-president of operations for Whistler-Blackcomb.

"We have fire hydrants for the snowmaking equipment and we have the ability to have some capable resources to help dampen the fire if we have anything start."

The forest fire on Blackcomb Mountain, which began Thursday afternoon after a lightning strike, is now estimated at 30 hectares, less than half of what officials had originally thought.

"Last night, we did some aerial flights with satellite imagery to get a more accurate size of the fire," fire information officer Phil Taudin-Chabot told media yesterday.

He said the blaze is now 30 per cent contained and there was no growth yesterday.

That update came as Premier Gordon Campbell implored British Columbians to stay out of the backcountry as they celebrate the long weekend, in order to prevent more forest fires.

About 85 per cent of the province is at a high or extreme fire hazard level, and it is costing the province about $3 million a day to fight the current fires, many of them caused by humans.

About 375 staff and guests on the ski hills above the village were forced to flee from Blackcomb and adjacent Whistler Mountains as a result of the fire. Some employees had to temporarily be evacuated from staff housing, though they were allowed back a short time later.

The Blackcomb Mountain fire is not currently a threat to homes. Taudin-Chabot said it is three kilometres uphill from any structures.

Blackcomb Mountain is home to the Olympic Sliding Centre, which will host the bobsleigh, luge and skeleton events during the 2010 Games. Whistler Mountain will host the alpine skiing events.

None of the Games venues is currently at risk.

In Lillooet, B.C., about 130 kilometres from Whistler, more than 2,300 residents have been put on evacuation alert as the Mount McLean forest fire continues to burn out of control.

DARRYL DYCK The Canadian Press A wildfire on Whistler's Blackcomb Mountain above Green Lake is much smaller than originally feared.

urn:contentItem:46YD-70C0-01G6-B524-00000-00<published>1999-04-23T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:17:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WESTERN REGIONAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Alta-Wildfires</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">INDEX: Environment, Technology, Business, Politics</p><p nitf:lede="true">EDMONTON -- Some lessons were learned last year when Alberta had one of its worst fire seasons on record.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The province will have faster forest fire response this year and a better way to track where those blazes are.</p><p>-BODY- New computer software and an expanded forest fire operations centre are in place to help the province manage wildfires better.</p><p>The charred ruins of Alberta forests cost the province 200-million dollars, just in fire fighting costs, last year.</p><p>The forestry industry is still tallying up the costs of lost timber. Alberta has purchased some slick new fire management computer software from B-C that will help deploy planes and firefighters to the right spots.</p><p>It will also show fires on a colourful map of the province as they happen, instead of staff having to make several phone calls for current information. Fire officials say conditions throughout the northern part of Alberta are dry. Three out-of-control fires are raging near Fort Vermillion, Peace River and Slave Lake, Alberta. Officials say the fire season could be as bad as it was last year, when over 16-hundred fires ate their way through 75-hundred square kilometres of forest. urn:contentItem:58C9-WRH1-JBVR-317R-00000-00Top News Advisory at 6:45 a.m. Wednesday, May 8, 20132013-05-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:17:34ZLexisNexisADVISORIES,NATIONALTop News Advisory at 6:45 a.m. Wednesday, May 8, 2013Top News AdvisoryThe Canadian Press

Wednesday, May 8, 2013

6:45 a.m..

Here are the latest Top News stories from The Canadian Press. All times are Eastern unless otherwise stated. Coverage plans are included when available. Entries are subject to change as news develops. Contact the National Desk at 416-507-2150.

___

TOP NEWS THIS HOUR

Emergency centre set up in New Brunswick town due to forest fire

NB-Forest-Fire

KEDGWICK, N.B. _ A reception centre has been set up in a community hall in a village in northwestern New Brunswick in case a forest fire forces people to flee their homes. However, a spokesman for the provincial Department of Natural Resources says the fire has "subsided substantially" Tuesday night and there were no evacuations in Kedgwick, about 300 kilometres north of Fredericton.

___

Canadian tourist dies after falling from hotel in Mexican resort

Mexico-Cda-Death

TORONTO _ A Canadian tourist has died in the Mexican resort of Cancun. Local media reports say the 21-year-old, identified as Sydney Taylor, died early Tuesday after apparently falling about 10 metres from the balcony of her second-floor hotel room. A spokesman for Acadia University in Nova Scotia says the victim graduated from the school last month. AUDIO

___

Conservatives raise fears of mentally ill with flawed crime bill, doctors say

Not-Criminally-Responsible

OTTAWA _ Mental health professionals from across Canada are banding together during Mental Health Week to ask the Harper government to rethink its latest crime bill. Nine different organizations, including their multiple provincial organizations, say changes to the Not Criminally Responsible regime for mentally ill offenders have been made without evidence or input from mental health workers. AUDIO

___

Belgian prosecutor: 31 people in 3 countries detained in airport diamond heist

EU-Belgium-Diamond-Heist

BRUSSELS, Belgium _ Police have carried out raids and detained 31 people in three countries in connection with a spectacular $50 million diamond heist pulled off with apparent clockwork precision at Brussels Airport, a Belgian prosecutor said Wednesday. One person was detained in France, six in Switzerland and 24 in Belgium in connection with the Feb. 19 robbery.

___

Bombing conspiracy suspect's father: son 'not a terrorist.'

US-Boston-Marathon-Explosions

BOSTON _ The father of a student charged with conspiracy in the Boston Marathon bombing case insists his son is not a terrorist and said the 19-year-old believes his friend Dzhokhar Tsarnaev is "not a human" if he's responsible for the attacks. Azamat Tazhayakov told The Associated Press that his he has visited his son once since arriving in the United States from Kazakhstan more than a week ago.

___

Attorneys say theatre shooting suspect wants to plead insanity

US-Colorado-Shooting

DENVER _ The man accused in the deadly Colorado theatre shootings wants to change his plea to not guilty by reason of insanity. James Holmes' attorneys revealed his intention Tuesday. Holmes is charged with multiple counts of murder and attempted murder in the July 20 attack that killed 12 people and left 70 injured.

___

Death toll from Bangladesh building collapse reaches 761

AS-Bangladesh-Building-Collapse

DHAKA, Bangladesh _ The death toll from a collapsed building housing five garment factories rose to 761 on Wednesday as authorities started disbursing salary and other benefits to the survivors in the country's deadliest industrial disaster. the eight-story Rana Plaza was packed with morning-shift workers when it collapsed on April 24 outside the nation's capital.

___

Italy cargo ship slams into Genoa port, killing 4 people@<

EU-Italy-Cargo-Ship-Crash

ROME _ At least four people died after a cargo ship slammed into a control tower in the Italian port of Genoa, toppling it into the harbour, rescue officials said Wednesday. A half-dozen other people remained unaccounted for, including some feared trapped inside the submerged elevator of the control tower. PHOTOS

___

Toyota quarterly profit more than doubles to $3.2 billion

AS-Japan-Earns-Toyota

TOKYO _ Toyota's quarterly profit more than doubled to $3.2 billion as cost cuts and better sales worked with a weakening yen to add momentum to the automaker's comeback. Toyota Motor Corp. said it expects the strong results to continue in its new business year that ends March 2014. PHOTOS

BUZZ

Stephen Hawking won't attend Israeli conference, cites 'personal reasons'

EU-Britain-Israel-Hawking

LONDON _ Physicist Stephen Hawking has dropped plans to attend a major conference in Israel in June. This prompted criticism Wednesday from Israeli officials who believe he has joined a boycott organized to protest Israel's treatment of the Palestinians.

___

Madonna's French painting sells in NYC for $7.2 million

US-Madonna-Leger-Auction

NEW YORK _ A French painting owned by Madonna has sold at a New York City auction for more than $7 million. Sotheby's auction house hasn't said who bought Fernand Leger's "Three Women at the Red Table" for $7.2 million on Tuesday. Proceeds will benefit the Ray of Light Foundation, which supports girls' education in Afghanistan, Pakistan and other countries.

___

Two of 3 Rodin sculptures sell at NYC auction for nearly $16 million

NY-Rodin-Sculptures-Auction

NEW YORK _ Two early casts from Auguste Rodin's masterpiece "The Gates of Hell" have sold for a total of more than $16 million at a New York City auction. "The Thinker" sold Tuesday for $15.3 million, a new record for the figure. Sotheby's hasn't said who bought it. A later cast of the statue was auctioned for just under $12 million in 2010. PHOTO

___

Authorities: Lead singer of As I Lay Dying tried to hire detective to kill wife

US-Metal-Singer-Murder-For-Hire

OCEANSIDE, Calif. _ The singer of Grammy-nominated heavy metal band As I Lay Dying has been arrested in Southern California after authorities say he tried to hire an undercover detective to kill his estranged wife. The San Diego County Sheriff's Department says 32-year-old Tim Lambesis was arrested Tuesday in Oceanside.

urn:contentItem:5V55-HF01-F103-31CN-00000-00DeVone Claybooks returns to Calgary Stampeders after diabetes diagnosis2018-08-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:17:33ZLexisNexisSPORTSDeVone Claybooks returns to Calgary Stampeders after diabetes diagnosis

CALGARY — Back on the football field after a diabetes scare, Calgary Stampeders defensive co-ordinator DeVone Claybrooks says he's not the only one keeping a watchful eye on his health.

"My mom is here running stuff, bossing me around like I'm 10 years old again," Claybrooks said Friday at McMahon Stadium.

The 40-year-old spent a week in hospital before he was released Wednesday.

No cable sports television in the hospital, Claybrooks listened on the radio as the Stampeders beat the Winnipeg Blue Bombers 39-26 last week.

Claybrooks was given the green light to return to Stampeder practice Friday, but he will take stock of his health before committing to be on the sidelines for Monday's Labour Day game against the visiting Edmonton Eskimos.

"If I'm comfortable enough, I'll do it," Claybrooks said. "If I'm not, we'll do it like we did last week.

"Guys held it down. There wasn't any drop-offs. We have a high standard here. We understand what level of competition we're facing this weekend."

The Stampeder defence has been the stingiest in the CFL in his two and half seasons as co-ordinator. His name was bandied about for vacant head coaching positions in the off-season.

Claybrooks, from Martinsville, Va., is in his seventh season on Calgary's coaching staff after three seasons playing on the team's defensive line.

A big man at six foot two and over 250 pounds, Claybrooks has a personality to match. Wearing his baseball cap with the brim at a rakish angle is his signature look.

The players felt a void during his absence.

"We were all on edge about what was really going on," defensive back Brandon Smith said. "Everyone has their own type of personality, but the personality that he brings, a lot of comedy, a lot of energy, some of the foul words he uses, we know he's around coaching.

"We definitely knew he was back today."

While diabetes runs in his family and his mother Sally Claybrooks has it, the diagnosis still came as a surprise to her son.

"I had no clue," Claybrooks said. "I had a family history of it, but I didn't have any idea of it at all."

Diabetes is a chronic disease in which the body either cannot produce insulin or cannot properly use the insulin it produces, according to Diabetes Canada, which also states there are 11 million Canadians living with diabetes or prediabetes.

Insulin is a hormone that controls the amount of sugar in the blood. Diabetes leads to high blood sugar levels, which can damage organs, blood vessels and nerves. The body needs insulin to use sugar as an energy source.

Claybrooks said he'd been feeling tired and thirsty and his vision was blurry, but chalked it up to working long hours and the forest fire smoke blanketing Calgary at the time.

"Basically just one morning, just woke up and my body just stopped processing the sugar and the glucose," he said.

He was rushed to hospital in an ambulance for treatment, and was told his blood sugar levels were alarmingly high.

"A few hours later, I probably wouldn't be here," Claybrooks said. "It's definitely an awakening. I've got to make some life changes as far as my diet and that type of thing."

Claybrooks says he's getting treatment for both Type 1 diabetes, in which the body doesn't make insulin, and Type 2, in which insulin isn't processed properly, until it becomes clear which type he has.

In the meantime, Claybrooks says he'll listen to what his body, and his mom, are telling him as he returns to work.

"First practice was great. I enjoyed it and missed the guys," he said. "Slimmed down a little bit. I've got four abs instead of two."

urn:contentItem:5WY1-93D1-JC13-H275-00000-00Selected to Perform System Design Phase for Wildfire Monitoring Satellite2019-08-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:17:34ZLexisNexisSelected to Perform System Design Phase for Wildfire Monitoring Satellite

MAXAR COMPANY ("MAXR-TN") - Selected to Perform System Design Phase for Wildfire - Monitoring Satellite

MDA, a Maxar company, has been awarded a contract from the Canadian Space Agency to execute the system design phase of a forest fire monitoring satellite called WildFireSat.

The purpose of the WildFireSat (WFS) mission would be to provide a space-based capability to increase Canada's ability to monitor wildland fires across the country, including near real-time information in support of wildland fire management and research, emission measurements in support of international carbon reporting requirements and improved smoke and air quality forecasting.

"MDA looks forward to working with the Canadian Space Agency, its government partners, and a great Canadian industrial team on the first phase of this important project that aims to improve Canada's ability to detect and monitor forest and other wildland fires," said Mike Greenley, group president of MDA. "This project will leverage MDA's world-leading satellite development and production capabilities, gained through being the Government of Canada's leading mission prime partner for satellite programs, including for the recently launched RADARSAT Constellation Mission."

On Phase A of the WFS project, MDA will work with the Canadian Space Agency, Natural Resources Canada's Canadian Forest Service, Environment and Climate Change Canada and potentially other government partners to develop a system concept for the WFS mission and derive system requirements, and to produce a mission development plan as well as cost estimates for future phases of the project. In addition, MDA plans to engage an impressive industrial team to deliver this Phase A design work.

About Maxar

Maxar is a trusted partner and innovator in Earth Intelligence and Space Infrastructure. We deliver disruptive value to government and commercial customers to help them monitor, understand and navigate our changing planet; deliver global broadband communications; and explore and advance the use of space. Our unique approach combines decades of deep mission understanding and a proven commercial and defense foundation to deploy solutions and deliver insights with unrivaled speed, scale and cost effectiveness. Maxar's 5,900 team members in 30 global locations are inspired to harness the potential of space to help our customers create a better world. Maxar trades on the New York Stock Exchange and Toronto Stock Exchange as MAXR. For more information, visit www.maxar.com.

About MDA, a Maxar company

MDA is an internationally recognized leader in space robotics, space sensors, satellite payloads, antennas and subsystems, surveillance and intelligence systems, defense and maritime systems, and geospatial radar imagery. MDA's extensive space expertise and heritage translates into mission-critical defence and commercial applications that include multi-platform command, control and surveillance systems, aeronautical information systems, land administration systems and terrestrial robotics. MDA is also a leading supplier of actionable mission-critical information and insights derived from multiple data sources. Founded in 1969, MDA is recognized as one of Canada's most successful technology ventures with locations in Richmond, Ottawa, Brampton, Montreal, Halifax and the United Kingdom. For more information visit www.mdacorporation.com.

(CP) - The teenage son of a firefighter has been charged with setting a massive forest fire that blazed out of control near this Okanagan Valley resort town for more than two weeks.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Jeremy Blake Kraiger, 19, appeared in provincial court Thursday on one charge of arson.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The fire destroyed 18 homes and forced more than 3,000 people to evacuate. It scorched about 5,500 hectares of forestry.</p><p>Hundreds of firefighters came to British Columbia to help fight the blaze. Firefighting costs were estimated at $3 million and the use of aircraft cost a further $2 million.</p><p>Kraiger is the son of Fred Kraiger, who has worked with the Penticton fire department since January 1986. The accused's father was one of the firefighters that tackled the blaze.</p><p>At his court appearance, Jeremy Kraiger looked wide-eyed and bewildered. Crown counsel Vernon Frolick said more charges are expected.</p><p>---</p><p>Two teenagers charged in death released on bail</p><p>VICTORIA (CP) - Two Victoria-area teenagers charged with the second-degree murder in the beating death of another 17-year-old youth were released on bail Thursday.</p><p>But a youth court judge ordered that they must live under house arrest with their parents.</p><p>They were charged after Andre Castet was beaten to death Monday night while several other teenagers watched on a street in nearby Sidney.</p><p>The teens, who cannot be identified because they are cherged under the Young Offenders Act, have been in custody since Tuesday night. Judge Keith Bracken also issued a ban on publication of the proceedings at the request of the defence.</p><p>---</p><p>Police search for car spotted near dead mother's home</p><p>CRANBROOK, B.C. (CP) - RCMP are searching for a car believed to have been near the home of a mother and her twin boys when they were killed last month and their townhouse set on fire.</p><p>The vehicle is described as a mid-1970s two-door Chevrolet Nova, possibly white in color. It has a black grill and black stripes along the side.</p><p>Police want to question the driver about his or her activities the night that Susan Roberts, 24, was found dead in her burned-out home July 18. The body of her 14-month-old son, Josiah, was found two days later at a nearby abandoned landfill.</p><p>Josiah's twin, David, died in hospital after suffering severe brain damage caused by smoke inhalation. A third son, Jonathan, was pulled from the burning house by a neighbor and survived.</p><p>The father, Dean Roberts, was out of the house at the time.</p><p>---</p><p>Natives concerned about aggressive fishing on West Coast</p><p>CHILLIWACK, B.C. (CP) - Only a small number of sockeye salmon have reached their spawning grounds so far this year, raising fears with one native band that the Canada-U.S. fish war might be depleting West Coast stocks.</p><p>The Sto:lo Fisheries Authority says only one-tenth the number of Stuart River sockeye expected to escape intensive fishing have arrived at their natal streams.</p><p>The native fishermen want answers from federal Fisheries Minister Brian Tobin, who has urged West Coast fishermen to take as many of the salmon as possible as they head for the Fraser River, leaving only leftovers for American fishermen.</p><p>---</p><p>Reform MP decries planned women's monument</p><p>VANCOUVER (CP) - A monument to honor women murdered by men is just another case of a special interest group hijacking the public purse for a tasteless cause, says a Reform party MP.</p><p>Ted White also said Thursday he was told by Alexandra Griffith, co-ordinator of the Women's Monument Project, that men cannot compete for the design award because of fears a male winner might later be found to have abused a child.</p><p>"It is my opinion such an attitude does nothing to foster good relationships between men and women,'' said White, who represents the North Vancouver riding.</p><p>The $300,000 monument, to be built in a Vancouver park, was sparked by the killings of 14 female engineering students in Montreal in 1989.</p><p>Organizers recently announced that 98 designs had been whittled to three, with a finalist to be announced Oct. 8.</p><p>Project committee member Lisa Brisebois said if Griffith made the comment, she was wrong.</p><p>---</p><p>Federal government gives Vancouver meagre amount, says alderman</p><p>VANCOUVER (CP) - Three left-hand turn lanes on city streets are Vancouver's share of the latest $13.5-million in federal money for infrastructure projects in British Columbia, city officials said Thursday.</p><p>It's a far cry from a $23-million hockey arena for Edmonton or $21 million for a convention centre in Quebec City.</p><p>"I feel like we got screwed again,'' said Vancouver Coun. George Puil.</p><p>The best he could say is that it will save one-third of the $690,000 total cost of the turning bays. The total cost of the 61 B.C. projects announced Thursday is $41 million with the federal, provincial and municipal governments each contributing one-third.</p><p>---</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:46YB-1060-01G6-B2B6-00000-00<published>1998-09-06T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:17:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WESTERN REGIONAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>--Prairie Update--</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">((CPR Grain Proposals))</p><p nitf:lede="true">Saskatchewan Transportation Minister Judy Bradley says grain producers could be hurt by C-P Rail's proposals to change the grain handling and transportation system.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The C-P-R has told a review of the system that there needs to be a more flexible car allocation process as well as direct shipper-carrier negotiations.</p><p nitf:lede="true">-BODY- Bradley says those changes would hurt grain farmers unless short-line rail co-ops are made more competitive.</p><p>She feels the C-P-R proposals would deregulate the system and increase the cost of moving grain for producers. (CKRM-s) ((Sask-Freezing))</p><p>Temperatures in the grain belt in northwestern Saskatchewan fell below freezing overnight -- but there are no reports of frost. There is a risk of frost tonight in the Yorkton area. (CKRM-s) ((Alta-Forest Fire))</p><p>A forest fire in Alberta's Waterton Lakes National Park has scorched about 13-hundred hectares of timberland.</p><p>The forest fire was started last week by a lightning strike.</p><p>About 200 firefighters are battling the flames.</p><p>Some areas of the park are closed because of the fire. (CHQR-s) ((Sask-Fatal))</p><p>The R-C-M-P have identified a man killed in a head-on truck collision near Coronach, Saskatchewan.</p><p>Two pick-up trucks collided at the crest of a hill near the town Friday.</p><p>Police say 42-year-old Graydon Travland of Coronach died in the crash.</p><p>The driver of the other truck was treated for minor injuries. (CKRM,CJWW) ((Sask-SIAST-Deal))</p><p>Unionized workers with the Saskatchewan Institute of Applied Science and Technology will vote on a tentative contract within the next three weeks.</p><p>Details of the proposed settlement will not be released until after ratification votes are held.</p><p>The Saskatchewan Government Employees' Union reached the deal with the institute late last week and the package affects about 16-hundred academic and administrative workers at five locations.</p><p>The Saskatchewan Institute of Applied Science and Technology is based in Saskatoon and has four campuses (Kelsey, Wascana, Palliser and Woodland). (CJWW,Release) ((Mba-Traffic-Fatals))</p><p>Two men are dead after their car hit a tree on a highway median in Winnipeg.</p><p>Thirty-five-year-old Gerald Rewucki (roo-ICK-e) and 26-six-year-old Leonard Sass died in the accident (on Henderson Highway) yesterday.</p><p>Winnipeg Police say high speed was a contributing factor. (CJOB-s) ---</p><p>(Prairie Update by Jim MacDonald)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5T5F-B0H1-DY9S-T0S3-00000-00DeVone Claybooks returns to Calgary Stampeders after diabetes diagnosis2018-08-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:17:33ZLexisNexisSPORTSDeVone Claybooks returns to Calgary Stampeders after diabetes diagnosisDeVone Claybrooks returns to StampedersDonna SpencerThe Canadian Press

CALGARY - Back on the football field after a diabetes scare, Calgary Stampeders defensive co-ordinator DeVone Claybrooks says he's not the only one keeping a watchful eye on his health.

"My mom is here running stuff, bossing me around like I'm 10 years old again," Claybrooks said Friday at McMahon Stadium.

The 40-year-old spent a week in hospital before he was released Wednesday.

No cable sports television in the hospital, Claybrooks listened on the radio as the Stampeders beat the Winnipeg Blue Bombers 39-26 last week.

Claybrooks was given the green light to return to Stampeder practice Friday, but he will take stock of his health before committing to be on the sidelines for Monday's Labour Day game against the visiting Edmonton Eskimos.

"If I'm comfortable enough, I'll do it," Claybrooks said. "If I'm not, we'll do it like we did last week.

"Guys held it down. There wasn't any drop-offs. We have a high standard here. We understand what level of competition we're facing this weekend."

The Stampeder defence has been the stingiest in the CFL in his two and half seasons as co-ordinator. His name was bandied about for vacant head coaching positions in the off-season.

Claybrooks, from Martinsville, Va., is in his seventh season on Calgary's coaching staff after three seasons playing on the team's defensive line.

A big man at six foot two and over 250 pounds, Claybrooks has a personality to match. Wearing his baseball cap with the brim at a rakish angle is his signature look.

The players felt a void during his absence.

"We were all on edge about what was really going on," defensive back Brandon Smith said. "Everyone has their own type of personality, but the personality that he brings, a lot of comedy, a lot of energy, some of the foul words he uses, we know he's around coaching.

"We definitely knew he was back today."

While diabetes runs in his family and his mother Sally Claybrooks has it, the diagnosis still came as a surprise to her son.

"I had no clue," Claybrooks said. "I had a family history of it, but I didn't have any idea of it at all."

Diabetes is a chronic disease in which the body either cannot produce insulin or cannot properly use the insulin it produces, according to Diabetes Canada, which also states there are 11 million Canadians living with diabetes or prediabetes.

Insulin is a hormone that controls the amount of sugar in the blood. Diabetes leads to high blood sugar levels, which can damage organs, blood vessels and nerves. The body needs insulin to use sugar as an energy source.

Claybrooks said he'd been feeling tired and thirsty and his vision was blurry, but chalked it up to working long hours and the forest fire smoke blanketing Calgary at the time.

"Basically just one morning, just woke up and my body just stopped processing the sugar and the glucose," he said.

He was rushed to hospital in an ambulance for treatment, and was told his blood sugar levels were alarmingly high.

"A few hours later, I probably wouldn't be here," Claybrooks said. "It's definitely an awakening. I've got to make some life changes as far as my diet and that type of thing."

Claybrooks says he's getting treatment for both Type 1 diabetes, in which the body doesn't make insulin, and Type 2, in which insulin isn't processed properly, until it becomes clear which type he has.

In the meantime, Claybrooks says he'll listen to what his body, and his mom, are telling him as he returns to work.

"First practice was great. I enjoyed it and missed the guys," he said. "Slimmed down a little bit. I've got four abs instead of two."

urn:contentItem:46YB-0XW0-01G6-B044-00000-00<published>1998-07-30T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:17:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>ATLANTIC REGIONAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>--Atlantic Update--</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">((NS-Premier-Port))</p><p nitf:lede="true">Nova Scotia's premier and cabinet were on the road to Sydney, today, but couldn't get away from Halifax business.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Premier Russell MacLellan admits the province is going to have to ''exert itself more'' in order to win important Halifax Port business.</p><p nitf:lede="true">-BODY- MacLellan was commenting, following an earlier demonstration by longshoremen outside Province House in Halifax.</p><p>The Premier said the province has been working very hard on a presentation which will be made to Maersk-Sealand. (CJCB) ((Nfld-Voisey's-Hurdle))</p><p>The Voisey's Bay development has cleared another major hurdle.</p><p>A Federal-Newfoundland assessment panel says it's ready to proceed to the next step in the environmental assessment review process.</p><p>Public hearings will begin September 9th.</p><p>The company will also have an opportunity to explain the project and respond to concerns and questions raised during the hearings. (VOCM) ((NS-Elderly-Death))</p><p>Amherst police have named the elderly man they say was the victim in a "suspicious death".</p><p>Earl Douglas Bishop of Amherst was 79.</p><p>He was found in an apartment last evening after a 9-1-1 call to police.</p><p>A female suspect is in custody, but charges have not been laid. (CKDH) ((NS-Forest-Fire))</p><p>Hot spots are all that remain of a forest fire that burned over eight-hectares of Nova Scotia Woodland.</p><p>The fire in Newtonville, Nova Scotia started as an industrial ''burn'' but spread quickly in gusty winds.</p><p>The forest fire hazard in the area remains extreme.(CKEN) ((NS-Yarmouth-Airport))</p><p>Travellers through the airport at Yarmouth, Nova Scotia will soon be greeted by an expansion.</p><p>Two levels of government have come together to help construct a new hangar and provide better freight-handling equipment.</p><p>Close to 450-thousand-dollars worth of improvements will also include better marketing of the Yarmouth airport. (BN-rls) ((PEI-Taxes))</p><p>A Prince Edward Island man is going back to jail for refusing to file his income-tax on time.</p><p>Ronald Lavers of Albion, P-E-I has already been sentenced on three different occasions for refusing to file his 1993 tax-return.</p><p>Deadlines came and went.</p><p>Today a judge sent Lavers back to jail for another six-months -- even though he finally filed his return this week. (CFCY)</p><p>(Atlantic Update by Jim Crichton)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:470S-HB60-01G6-8513-00000-00<published>1994-09-27T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:17:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WESTERN REGIONAL GENERAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>PM-Alta-Forest-Fires, DL, 1st Ld ; CGY OUT CQQ; Day Lead; 1st Lead; Changing weather aids forest fire fight</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>ROCKY MOUNTAIN HOUSE, Alta.</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>ROCKY MOUNTAIN HOUSE, Alta. (CP) - Cool, calm weather is helping firefighters douse two out-of-control forest fires along the foothills today.</p><p nitf:lede="true">One fire covering over 300 hectares about 40 kilometres southwest of Rocky Mountain House is expected to be brought under control by tonight, said Mike Dubina, operations dispatcher for the Alberta Forest Service.</p><p>And the growth of a second blaze about 120 kilometres west of the city, which has flared from 16 hectares to 260 since Friday, should also be checked by the evening, Dubina said.</p><p>Rocky Mountain House is 90 kilometres west of Red Deer.</p><p>"The weather's changed,'' said Dubina.</p><p>"It's cooler. The winds have gone down and we're expecting rain the next day or so. These things all help.''</p><p>The second blaze was believed to have begun at an abandoned campfire. But a tinder-dry forest floor combined with strong winds during the weekend fanned its speedy growth.</p><p>Steep slopes made it difficult to fight the flames from the ground and high winds made it too dangerous to launch an air attack earlier, said Ted Flanders of the Alberta Forest Service.</p><p>The first fire began as a prescribed burn - a fire that forest service officials intentionally lit in response to a request from Alberta's Fish and Wildlife department.</p><p>An elk herd in the area has grown so large, now totalling about 225 animals, that most edible foliage has disappeared.</p><p>Fish and Wildlife authorities asked for a prescribed burn in a thickly forested area nearby, so new foliage would begin growing next spring and provide an alternate food supply for the elk.</p><p>Forest service staff agreed, and took various precautionary measures including clearing away strips of forest to stop flames from spreading further before they began torching any trees.</p><p>But relatively minor winds suddenly switched direction and escalated to 60 kilometres per hour.</p><p>"Nothing could stop it,'' Flanders said. "It went right up the valley.''</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5S63-FM01-JDH3-G30N-00000-00High fire danger days expected to increase in Houston2018-04-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:17:33ZLexisNexisLOCAL-NEWSHigh fire danger days expected to increase in Houston

The Houston area could see an increase in the high/extreme fire danger days in the coming years due to climate change, which is creating drier forest conditions, a shift in vegetation and changes in weather patterns.

That's according to Houston's Community Wildfire Protection Plan (CWPP), prepared by Pro-Tech Forest Resources in December and recently reviewed by council.

According to the CWPP, longer fire seasons and an increase in forest fire frequency are expected as a result of climate change.

"We are witnessing earlier melts in spring, warmer temperatures during the winter than we saw historically 30 years or more ago," states the CWPP. "The impacts of the changing climate are not fully understood as of yet and this issue will continue to develop as the effects become apparent."

According to data collected from 1980 to 2017 at Dungate, Houston's closest weather station, the Houston area has seen an average of 37 days of "high" fire danger rating per year, and about 10 days of "extreme" rating.

Although 10 days may not seem concerning, the report notes that extreme fire behaviour can also be present when the rating is "high."

Some Houston area residences would be at higher risk due to their location adjacent to surrounding forest. These include the areas near Lund Road, Dungate Estates, Buck Flats Road, Cantor and North Road.

One of the CWPP's recommendations is for the District of Houston to invest in a sprinkler system that could be deployed at strategic locations during a wildfire event. This would help mitigate risk to hazardous values and critical infrastructure.

The CWPP also outlines the implementation of various fuel management techniques such as harvesting, thinning and pruning, as well as creating fuel breaks, which are designed to modify fire behaviour and improve suppresion outcomes.

Has Houston ever had a large wildfire?

To date there have been no large fires recorded in the District of Houston that have threatened the community, according to Houston's Community Wildfire Protection Plan (CWPP).

The nearest largest fire in recent history was the Swiss fire in 1983, which although some residences of Buck Flats Road were evacuated, the District of Houston was not affected in this manner.

In 2010 there was another fire located 30 km southwest of town that impacted residences on Buck Flats, and in 2014 there was a fire 20 km to the east of Houston that impacted the residences close to the fire. However, none of these fires directly impacted the District of Houston.

Although there is evidence that some large fires occurred before 1982, it is unknown what impact these fires had on the community at the time and if they caused any evacuations. In the 1920s there was a large fire north of Houston that ran all the way to Granisle, but no documentation of its impact was found, according to the CWPP.

Houston not a FireSmart certified community

The District of Houston has been encouraging residents to reduce fuel hazards through public awareness and education on FireSmart principles by distributing pamphlets.

However, there are no other education strategies being implemented, according to Houston's Community Wildfire Protection Plan (CWPP). The CWPP recommends Houston to apply for FireSmart funding to help establish other education strategies.

Meanwhile Burns Lake, a neighbouring community of similar size, became FireSmart certified last year. The certification encourages local groups to implement solutions to protect people and properties from wildfire.

Houston Today asked the District of Houston if the municipality is considering applying to become FireSmart certified. However, the district did not respond by press time.

urn:contentItem:5V02-B431-F103-31GV-00000-00Emma Teitel: Why does the most 'politically correct' generation keep throwing gender reveal parties?2018-12-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:17:33ZLexisNexisOPINIONPg. 0Emma Teitel: Why does the most 'politically correct' generation keep throwing gender reveal parties?Emma Teitel

If you want to dispel the myth that everyone under age 35 is a rigid adherent of political correctness, type three words into your internet search bar: gender reveal party. What you'll see is a very old-fashioned idea popularized by young people and new technology.

The gender reveal party-a soirée typically thrown by expectant parents to "reveal" the gender (or to be accurate, the biological sex) of their baby to friends and family-is consistently in the news these days because it paints a picture of millennials that is very different from the one we are used to seeing. It paints a picture of young parents who don't reject outdated gender stereotypes but rather, who fervently embrace them.

Céline Dion may have recently launched a gender-neutral clothing label whose colours consist predominantly of grey and black, but all over YouTube, Instagram, and Pinterest, people half her age are baking baby pink cupcakes to celebrate a girl in utero, and crocheting baby blue booties in honour of a boy on the way.

But these parties are also in the news because they tend to be tacky in the extreme and occasionally, dangerous. Last year an Arizona border patrol agent shot a rifle at a target containing tannerite, a highly explosive substance. The target was supposed to release a blue or pink dust upon impact-revealing the sex of the agent's future child. Instead the thing exploded, starting a forest fire that would scorch more than 45,000 acres and cost more than $8 million in damages.

Earlier this year, a Louisiana man dropped a jello-infused watermelon into the jaws of his pet alligator who immediately chomped down on the fruit causing it to ooze blue. Translation: It's a boy. Mazel tov.

This month, Nicole "Snooki" Polizzi, the most memorable star of the 2000s' reality TV show Jersey Shore, and ironically one of the least traditional people to ever grace the earth, threw her own bash in honour of traditional gender norms. Snooki, who is expecting her third child, video blogged her gender reveal party (complete with baby blue and baby pink decorated cannoli), an event at which her husband pitched her six-year-old son a novelty baseball that exploded into a plume of blue smoke when it hit his bat. Another boy. Mazel Tov.

Watch a few of these videos online and the reactions are almost always more enthusiastic-more joyous-when the reveal is a male one. I always look at the faces of the little girls in the crowd at these parties. What is going through their minds when they see all the men in their lives-fathers, brothers, uncles- pumping their fists in triumph through blue smoke and blue balloons? I'll never know, but I can't imagine that it will serve them well in the future.

Of course it makes sense that expectant parents want to learn as much as they can about their future kids, and biological sex is one of the only things we are able to learn about a baby before it's born. I can imagine the urge is very strong to know this and more critically, to celebrate it. But I also come from a culture that doesn't typically even do baby showers on account of superstition. And I maintain (even though I've attended several) that any party-shower or gender reveal-that occurs before a baby's birth is a little weird.

It just seems wise, in my mind, to wait until your kid enters the world before you start amassing a bunch of stuff in their name. Gender reveal parties are not all that different from baby showers, except that the parents who throw them don't amass material things. They amass presumptions. They presume to know something about their kids they can't possibly know. Blue and pink aren't just different colours. Even now, they're different worlds. Even now blue world trumps pink world.

Everyone learns this eventually. But I'm going to guess that kids whose parents assign so much importance to biological sex they are willing to explode small objects in the backyard, learn this sooner than they should.

Emma Teitel is a columnist based in Toronto covering current affairs. Follow her on Twitter: @emmaroseteitel

urn:contentItem:5JJS-1981-DY91-K2SY-00000-00Who responds when a crisis is declared?2016-04-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:17:33ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. A4Who responds when a crisis is declared?

What is an "emergency?"

The federal government, which has ultimate responsibility for First Nations in Canada, defines an emergency as a "present or imminent event that requires prompt co-ordination of actions concerning persons or property to protect the health, safety or welfare of people, or to limit damage to property or the environment." It could be a forest fire, spring flooding, a missing person, a rash of suicides or even the rapid spread of a communicable disease.

Who helps?

Ontario, along with Alberta, Saskatchewan and British Columbia, has an agreement with Ottawa whereby the province provides assistance with emergency preparedness and response while the federal government picks up the tab. The province has responded to 21 declarations of states of emergency on First Nations reserves since 2014, according to a provincial government spokesperson. Thirteen are ongoing, while eight have concluded.

Who is in charge?

Under the federal government's emergency management plan, it is First Nations governments who must create and put in place emergency plans. Help can be requested from the provincial government or outside organizations, but the federal government will only co-ordinate emergency logistics if expressly requested.

The response

It obviously varies depending on the type of emergency. In the case of floods and fires, it could involve evacuation from reserves. In health emergencies, medical professionals, counsellors and mental-health workers can be brought in for weeks to deal with the crisis. The government was criticized in the 2013 auditor general's report for spending the bulk of its money responding to and recovering from emergencies. But in the three-year period covered by the examination, only $4 million went toward preventing and mitigating emergencies.

The end

Just as it is up to First Nations governments to declare a state of emergency, it is up to them to decide when the crisis has passed.

That can be a simple calculation when it involves a washed-out bridge being rebuilt or a water filtration plant being repaired, but is much more complex when the emergency is a string of suicides or suicide attempts for which the medicine is somehow healing the pain and despair caused by several generations of abuse, drug use or unemployment.

Sources: Library of Parliament Research Report: "Emergency Management on First Nations Reserves"; fall 2013 report of the Auditor-General of Canada

-Allan Woods

Video shows Arizona wildfire started with gender reveal party

Opinion | Emma Teitel: Céline Dion is off-colour when it comes to kids' clothes

Opinion | Emma Teitel: Millennials aren't having less sex than previous generations. They're just the first to admit the truth

Of course it makes sense that expectant parents want to learn as much as they can about their future kids, and biological sex is one of the only things we are able to learn about a baby before it's born. I can imagine the urge is very strong to know this and more critically, to celebrate it. But I also come from a culture that doesn't typically even do baby showers on account of superstition. And I maintain (even though I've attended several) that any party-shower or gender reveal-that occurs before a baby's birth is a little weird.

It just seems wise, in my mind, to wait until your kid enters the world before you start amassing a bunch of stuff in their name. Gender reveal parties are not all that different from baby showers, except that the parents who throw them don't amass material things. They amass presumptions. They presume to know something about their kids they can't possibly know. Blue and pink aren't just different colours. Even now, they're different worlds. Even now blue world trumps pink world.

Everyone learns this eventually. But I'm going to guess that kids whose parents assign so much importance to biological sex they are willing to explode small objects in the backyard, learn this sooner than they should.

Emma Teitel is a columnist based in Toronto covering current affairs. Follow her on Twitter: @emmaroseteitel

urn:contentItem:5NF3-YSX1-F105-62FX-00000-00A 'roller-coaster of emotions'2017-04-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:17:33ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. A3A 'roller-coaster of emotions'Fort Mac man won $400,000, helped his family and gave to charitiesLauren KrugelThe Canadian Press

Between May and December of last year, Chris Flett went through two life-changing events:

his house burned down and he won the lottery.

Flett, 34, recalls fetching his daughter from school and rushing home to grab some of his belongings as a forest fire began to threaten his hometown of Fort McMurray.

The fire, nicknamed "the beast" for its ferocity and unpredictability, began burning deep in the bush about May 1 and spread into the northern Alberta city on May 3, forcing 88,000 people from their homes for a month or more.

In all, almost 2,600 dwellings were

destroyed, including Flett's house in

the hard-hit Beacon Hill neighbourhood.

Flett, business agent with the International Union of Operating Engineers, went back in early June with some friends to take stock of the damage.

"It was incredibly tough to watch everything you worked for in your life to be sitting there and be nothing but ashes."

He dug through the rubble for six straight days in 30 C heat.

"Came out with a couple of pieces of metal and a couple pieces of porcelain, some old tools."

The only thing he could recover of any sentimental value was a piece of a family urn.

Flett's fortunes shifted six months later when he won more than $400,000 in the Stollery Children's Hospital Foundation Mighty Millions Lottery 50/50 jackpot.

"Disbelief, probably a little bit of fear, happy, sad," Flett says of his reaction to the win.

"It was a roller-coaster of emotions, it really was."

With the cash infusion, Flett didn't have to make concessions as he planned the rebuild of his home. He was also able to help out his mother, whose home was underinsured, and his younger brother, who had no insurance for the place he was renting with friends.

So far, he's given $35,000 to $40,000 to charities that helped out with the disaster and intends to donate more.

Teen Time of Edmonton has been a priority. The charity, which runs Christian summer camps at a ranch north of Edmonton, took in many Fort McMurray evacuees, including Flett, his fiancée and eight-year-old daughter.

After months spent at the ranch, in his camper, with friends and lastly in a rented house, Flett and his family are looking forward to settling into their newly built home in Beacon Hill in June.

As the one-year mark since the fire nears, emotions are mixed.

"There's still pain. You still suffer. Every now and then you go to grab something and you realize you don't own that anymore and that doesn't exist anymore.

"But for the most part, we've stayed in a good spot, because we've made really good progress."

urn:contentItem:5C8B-VVD1-JBVR-33XK-00000-00Fire threatening Stanley Mission contained, second fire continues to grow2014-05-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:17:33ZLexisNexisWEATHER,PRAIRIES/BCFire threatening Stanley Mission contained, second fire continues to growFire threatening Stanley Mission containedThe Canadian Press

STANLEY MISSION, Sask. - Officials with the Lac La Ronge Indian Band and province continue to monitor the forest fire situation in Stanley Mission in northern Saskatchewan.

More than 200 people were evacuated when two fires came dangerously close to local buildings.

Duane McKay, Saskatchewan's Commissioner of Emergency Management and Fire Safety, says the wildfires were battled both from air and ground.

He says the closest fire, called the Lagoon fire, has been knocked down and contained.

A second fire, just north of Pelican Narrows, has grown to five square kilometres.

McKay says smoke in the area has been a concern and a number of agencies have been involved in the evacuation effort.

"Provincial Red Cross is up there, rapid response teams from the province are there and we are coordinating with all of the provincial authorities to make sure that the band has all of the support that they require," he says, adding that conditions are very dry across the north.

Val Nicholson, an official with the Prince Albert Fire Centre, says with the warm and dry weather the number of reported fires continues to grow.

"There are 12 fires burning in the province today, seven that aren't contained, which is about the same as yesterday," she says. "We've had 115 fires to date this year but 62 have been in the last seven days so as the temperature comes up we can see that things do dry out and people really should be cautious."

(CJLR)

urn:contentItem:5TYS-NF11-F103-31RV-00000-00Emma Teitel: A generation that seems to pride itself on political correctness makes garish displays of an outdated tradition2018-12-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:17:33ZLexisNexisOPINIONPg. 0Emma Teitel: A generation that seems to pride itself on political correctness makes garish displays of an outdated traditionEmma Teitel

If you want to dispel the myth that everyone under age 35 is a rigid adherent of political correctness, type three words into your internet search bar: gender reveal party. What you'll see is a very old-fashioned idea popularized by young people and new technology.

The gender reveal party-a soirée typically thrown by expectant parents to "reveal" the gender (or to be accurate, the biological sex) of their baby to friends and family-is consistently in the news these days because it paints a picture of millennials that is very different from the one we are used to seeing. It paints a picture of young parents who don't reject outdated gender stereotypes but rather, who fervently embrace them.

Céline Dion may have recently launched a gender-neutral clothing label whose colours consist predominantly of grey and black, but all over YouTube, Instagram, and Pinterest, people half her age are baking baby pink cupcakes to celebrate a girl in utero, and crocheting baby blue booties in honour of a boy on the way.

But these parties are also in the news because they tend to be tacky in the extreme and occasionally, dangerous. Last year an Arizona border patrol agent shot a rifle at a target containing tannerite, a highly explosive substance. The target was supposed to release a blue or pink dust upon impact-revealing the sex of the agent's future child. Instead the thing exploded, starting a forest fire that would scorch more than 45,000 acres and cost more than $8 million in damages.

Earlier this year, a Louisiana man dropped a jello-infused watermelon into the jaws of his pet alligator who immediately chomped down on the fruit causing it to ooze blue. Translation: It's a boy. Mazel tov.

This month, Nicole "Snooki" Polizzi, the most memorable star of the 2000s' reality TV show Jersey Shore, and ironically one of the least traditional people to ever grace the earth, threw her own bash in honour of traditional gender norms. Snooki, who is expecting her third child, video blogged her gender reveal party (complete with baby blue and baby pink decorated cannoli), an event at which her husband pitched her six-year-old son a novelty baseball that exploded into a plume of blue smoke when it hit his bat. Another boy. Mazel Tov.

Watch a few of these videos online and the reactions are almost always more enthusiastic-more joyous-when the reveal is a male one. I always look at the faces of the little girls in the crowd at these parties. What is going through their minds when they see all the men in their lives-fathers, brothers, uncles- pumping their fists in triumph through blue smoke and blue balloons? I'll never know, but I can't imagine that it will serve them well in the future.

Of course it makes sense that expectant parents want to learn as much as they can about their future kids, and biological sex is one of the only things we are able to learn about a baby before it's born. I can imagine the urge is very strong to know this and more critically, to celebrate it. But I also come from a culture that doesn't typically even do baby showers on account of superstition. And I maintain (even though I've attended several) that any party-shower or gender reveal-that occurs before a baby's birth is a little weird.

It just seems wise, in my mind, to wait until your kid enters the world before you start amassing a bunch of stuff in their name. Gender reveal parties are not all that different from baby showers, except that the parents who throw them don't amass material things. They amass presumptions. They presume to know something about their kids they can't possibly know. Blue and pink aren't just different colours. Even now, they're different worlds. Even now blue world trumps pink world.

Everyone learns this eventually. But I'm going to guess that kids whose parents assign so much importance to biological sex they are willing to explode small objects in the backyard, learn this sooner than they should.

urn:contentItem:5TYN-3X61-JDH1-C1Y2-00000-00Creston motel may soon be allowed to rent rooms by the month2018-12-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:17:33ZLexisNexisNEWSCreston motel may soon be allowed to rent rooms by the month

By Brian Lawrence

A Northwest Boulevard motel may soon be allowed to rent rooms by the month, after Creston town council passed two readings of a proposed bylaw amendment at its regular meeting on Dec. 11.

Developer David Derkatch applied for the rezoning, requiring it as a condition of purchasing the Mountain View Inn at 1441 Northwest Blvd., with the goal of creating affordable housing.

"It would definitely take up a … big hole in the market" said Derkatch, who had a similar rezoning request approved by Cranbrook city council on Monday.

Built in 1960, the motel is currently zoned for tourist commercial use, and long-term monthly rentals are not permitted.

"They're allowed nightly, weekly at the outside," said municipal services director Ross Beddoes.

The site is located outside the Official Community Plan's residential growth containment area, but the fact that the units already exist and serve an important demographic earned the proposal the support of the Creston Valley Community Housing Society.

A public hearing — which could result in a third reading and approval — for the zoning amendment will be held at a special council meeting on Jan. 15, 2019.

Council Briefs

•Council passed the first and second readings of a zoning amendment to bylaw 1877, which will allow cannabis cultivation and research in the community. The proposed amendment includes, among other components, repealing the temporary prohibition on cannabis retail and cultivation, definitions of cannabis-related land uses and associated terms, 150-metre buffers around parks and schools, the addition of "cannabis operation" in the agriculture zone, and the addition of fencing and screening requirements.

When Coun. Jim Elford asked about the need for screened or blacked-out windows, citing the Union of BC Municipalities (UBCM) preference for clear windows, Beddoes explained that covered windows are required by the Interior Health Authority.

A public hearing for the amendment will be held Jan. 15, 2019.

•If the Creston Valley Regional Airport Society approves the Creston Valley Cruisers request to hold a drag race event on June 8, 2019, the town, which owns the property, will likely follow suit. The Cruisers had previously been approved to hold the event in September, but the airport became unavailable due to heavy aircraft use during forest fire season. The car club expects about 64 cars to race, with spectators numbering between 1,000 and 1,500.

•The Town of Creston will spend $150 from the mayor's discretionary fund to sponsor the Creston Valley Chamber of Commerce's Jan. 10 breakfast meeting at the Creston and District Community Complex. Mayor Ron Toyota will attend with Coun. Ellen Tzakis, council's representative to the chamber, and also make a presentation.

•On the recommendation of interim town manager Michael Moore, council authorized the Regional District of Central Kootenay to submit an application for $25,000 from the UBCM Community Resiliency Investment Grant Program on behalf of the town. The funds would be used to continue participating in the regional FireSmart program, as the town did this year.

•Council approved an updated flag protocol policy, rescinding previous policies in the council policy manual. The town will now follow raise, lower, fly, maintain and dispose of flags in accordance with Canadian Heritage's guidelines on Flag Etiquette in Canada and Rules for Flying the Flag.

•The Creston Lions Club will be granted an occupation licence to use the Millennium Park parking lot for its annual Christmas tree chipping event.

•A development permit application by Tom Boese on behalf of Arrow Mountain Car Wash and Mini Storage was approved. It will allow the construction of a new mini-storage building at 1236 Northwest Blvd.

•Council approved the disbursement of $2,100 in discretionary funds, the remainder of a $7,000 allotment for 2018 that will not carry over into 2019.

Toyota donated the final $850 of his discretionary fund to Creston's branch of the Royal Canadian Legion. Council members used $800 from their fund to cover rental fees at the Creston and District Community Complex for the Creston Ministerial Association's Christmas hamper program, and $450 would go to Juice FM's Dec. 14 fundraiser for the Creston Valley Hospital.

•Beddoes reported that the town has received 48 responses to the Citizen Budget, an interactive budget simulator that allows residents to provide feedback on civic services as part of the town's 2019 budget consultation. The five-minute survey can be filled out online or on iPads at Town Hall.

urn:contentItem:5T38-1YY1-F105-61TP-00000-00Hamilton hit with 'delightfully boring' weather this summer2018-08-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:17:33ZLexisNexisNEWSHamilton hit with 'delightfully boring' weather this summernpaddon@thespec.com

While it might seem like this summer has been punctuated by scorching hot periods and intense downpours, it's been about as close to a "normal" season as Hamilton is likely to get.

It's not over yet, but the first few months of summer have been "delightfully boring" - not excessively wet or dry with "persistently warm" temperatures, according to David Phillips, senior climatologist with Environment Canada.

"It's been almost the Goldilocks of summers," he said. "It's not been record hot. It's not been record dry. It's been almost a nice kind of balance there."

Phillips noted that some of this summer's rain fell in "heavy doses," which could lead to flooding, like what Toronto experienced earlier this month. But that also means the dreary weather was over in "one bout."

"There were a lot of days that were dry, dry, dry," he said, noting only 36 days have been wet out of 113 since May 1 in Hamilton.

Environment Canada issued a severe thunderstorm watch for Hamilton Tuesday afternoon, calling for possibly dangerous thunderstorms capable of producing strong wind gusts and torrential rains.

Heavy downpours could cause flash floods and water pooling on roads, the federal agency warned.

This was the third time this month that southern Ontario was in line to get soaked by a significant rainfall. Earlier in the day, Environment Canada also issued a special weather statement for Toronto, the Windsor and Sarnia areas as well as the North Bay, Parry Sound and Huntsville areas.

As for this summer's temperatures, Hamilton has not seen record-breaking conditions, but it has been far better than last year, Phillips said.

In 2017, Hamilton saw two days where the temperature reached 30 C. There were more days last fall where the temperature was that hot, he said.

So far this summer, we've already had 15 days, he added.

"Last year was a real bummer of a summer, and hey, this one's a hummer," he said.

Looking ahead, Phillips said it looks like September will be wetter and warmer than normal.

Compared to what other areas of the country have had to deal with, from heat and drought on the prairies to forest fires in British Columbia and northern Ontario, Hamilton has had it easy.

"My sense is that people never appreciate it until it's over," Phillips said.

Northern and central Ontario forest fires have had an impact on the sunsets and sunrises across southern and eastern Ontario, including Hamilton, according to Phillips.

Reports of brilliant orange hues can be attributed to travelling forest fire smoke in the upper atmosphere, he said.

"When the sun sets, it helps to scatter the sunshine, and so it produces that very orangey kind of just a beautiful look to the sky and to the sunsets," he said. "It's a matter of how the sunlight coming from a setting sun or a rising sun is in fact reflected and refracted because of impurities in the air."

Because it is dry, there are not clouds blocking or intervening, he said.

Samantha Yammine, a PhD candidate at the University of Toronto and a science communicator who goes by the name "Science Sam," said she started looking into social media posts she noticed over the weekend in which people reported seeing a brighter, more orangey-red sun. Some even noticed a haziness outside, she said.

Using publicly-available data tracking the BC fires and satellite data from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), Yammine said it seems the smoke is coming from that direction opposed to from northern Ontario. But there is less complete data for the fires in this province, she noted.

As of Tuesday, smoke coverage in the Hamilton and Greater Toronto Area seemed to have cleared and was expected to remain that way for the next 48 hours, said Yammine, noting the local air quality health index was hovering around "low risk" range.

It's not the first time in history in which smoke has travelled from the fire's origin, but the conditions need to be right for it to happen, she said, pointing to hot conditions combined with strong winds.

The Department of Health has the air and road ambulance people on standby.''</p><p>So far, Adams-Bower said, no moves have been made to evacuate whole towns or villages in the path of the fires.</p><p>Saskatchewan fire officials said Thursday there are 63 fires burning in the province, 11 are listed as being out of control.</p><p>The village most at risk is La Loche, where a forest fire is burning about eight kilometres from the town.</p><p>There are several small fires burning near the community of 1,600, most were started during a lightning storm earlier this week.</p><p>The Ile-a-la-Crosse blaze, which is burning about 10 kilometres south of the village, has consumed about 7.6 square kilometres of tinder-dry timber is the biggest fire in the region.</p><p>Ile-a-la-Crosse is under no immediate threat because it's separated from the fire by an arm of the Churchill River.</p><p>Adams-Bower says her department will team up with the Red Cross to provide evacuation and registration centres if evacuations are ordered.</p><p>If there are members of the public who have to be evacuated and they don't have a family member or a friend's place to go to, then they can go to our reception centre which could be in a school gym or a gym on a reserve if there is one close.</p><p>"They register with the Red Cross and then our staff works to relocate them in a safe place if they have to be there for any length of time and ensure they have the necessities of life, that sort of thing.''</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4J9M-8X80-TX77-D2V5-00000-00Raging inferno sends smoke2001-10-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:17:34ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5Raging inferno sends smokeJohnnie BachuskyRed Deer Express

An out-of-control forest fire southwest of Sundre is now an advancing inferno heading east with more than 5,000 hectares of forest already engulfed in flames.

The blaze has forced evacuations, road closures and health advisories even in the city of Red Deer where ash was falling from the sky as early as Tuesday evening.

The province has dispatched more than 100 firefighters to the scene, now considered Central Alberta's largest forest fire of the year.

As of Wednesday, the fire was raging about 50 kms southwest of Sundre and 130 kms from Red Deer, with its leading eastern perimeter almost two kilometres wide and at least four kilometre long, said Alberta forestry spokesperson Lisa Block.

She said only a provincial ranger station at Blue Hill Tower was evacuated. Block said staff at Mountain Aire Lodge, located between the Red Deer and Panther rivers about eight kms from the fire, and at Yaha-Tinda Ranch, 15 km from the blaze, were told to be on standby. However, guests at the lodge have been evacuated and the road to the ranch is now closed as fire has spread to both sides.

She said recreation sites, gas wells and a Shell Canada oilfield office in the area were not immediately threatened.

``Roadblocks have been set up but we are allowing people in who have a reason to be there,'' said Block.

She said about 2.5 cm of snow fell on the blaze Tuesday night, offering some hope for firefighters and helicopter crews.

``It most definitely helped. The cool temperatures did as well,'' said Block.

By late afternoon Tuesday, smoke from the fire was filling the evening sky in Red Deer.

Ted Hickey, deputy chief at Red Deer Emergency Services, said a ``few'' people called 911 not knowing the origins of the smoke.

``We hope this doesn't escalate,'' said Hickey. ``But anytime you do get an air quality issue we want to heighten awareness for people who have chronic lung difficulties.''

By Wednesday morning, the southwesterly winds had changed direction and the smoke cleared from the city area.

The fire, which originated Sept. 30 from a controlled burn in the front ranges of the Rocky Mountains, flared out of control Tuesday, said Kevin Gagne, fire information officer for Alberta Sustainable Resource Development.

By late Tuesday afternoon, the blaze was moving eastward and covering an area of more than 1,000 hectares.

``The active area is small but it's volatile,'' said Gagne. ``One finger of it is moving eastward and has crossed the Red Deer River.''

Earlier this year, there was a major forest fire near Abraham Lake and another north of Nordegg but neither was as serious as the current blaze, said Gagne.

Thank you to the fire departments of Maple Bay, Duncan, Crofton, Chemainus, Ladysmith and Cedar, and to Paul Belgens and his crew who supplied water trucks.

Janet and I would like to thank all the fire departments who came to the call on Aug. 25 on Panorama Ridge. They worked very, very hard to save our log home, and to save the entire community from a forest fire. They worked for several hours to stop the fire from spreading from the roof system to the main floor of our home.

Those men and women are extremely hard working people from all parts of our beautiful Cowichan Valley that volunteer their time and lives to save homes and lives. We cannot thank them enough.

With extreme gratitude… Chuck and Janet Moore Chemainus
